Posted: June 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is brilliant. For a game still in development, it is surprisingly good. One of my favourite top-down games ever. Easy enough to understand, but with a great deal of versatility in regards to how you wish to play out each mission. Do you go slowly from room to room, checking past each door with a spy camera, or just charge in with shotguns, grenades and breaching charges? This game can also be quite challenging, which means completion of a difficult mission actually feels like an achievment. I'm hoping as development goes forward the variety of weapons, tools, tactics and missions  will all increase, so you can play the game entirely your way.

Posted: April 7, 2015
												As a tactical command game, Door kickers is amazingly satisfying.The missions are fair, and are never forced to be unreasonably hard, with a bit of thought all missions can be completed without casualties.What really makes this game shine is the modability.You can spend hours playing around with the features of this, and the Devs have done a good job to make it accesable.Highly recommend this to any breachers in waiting.

Posted: June 15, 2015
												I've got a little more than an hour into this game, and I have to say, it is thrilling. It reminds me a lot of the old SWAT2 title, but far more approchable. If you're into puzzle games, where you can pause the action to try and compose yourself, and think about your next move, than this is for you. I belive this is my favorite part. I'll use my units to clear each room, one at a time, pausing to figure out the next steps. Does it always go to plan? Hell no, but i have a LOT of fun failing. I've had my eye on this game for a few months, and I really wish I picked it up sooner.

Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Door Kickers is a top-down stradegy game where you control SWAT members, each with his own stats.BETA VERSION: Some stuff here is subject to change, so when you play it may be different! These are my opinions about it all!Pros:+Members have different stats that increase as they gain experience through missions.+Style and elements are very good and work with the game exceptionally well.+Take down hostiles however you want, stealth or guns blazing (which is difficult)+Weapons and Armor are unlockable as you beat levels!+Badge can be customized off real ones, like NYPD+Random Mission Generator is fun to mess with adn what you will use the most, probably+Very Neat Replay system, enjoyable to watch yourself decimate your enemies in slow motion+STEAM WORKSHOP is amazing with thisNeither:-+The exeperience system takes a long time to get the breacher and Stealth class and requires more play time to unlock.-+Workshop is (Version 0.1.1) currently broken and hardly any good mods work :(-+Bugs, but it is in BETA so can't complainCons:-The pathing system has a hard time getting past obstacles like benchs, etc.-Armor is a pain to unlock, besides the Extended Armor which is 5 stars.-Random Mission Generator stars dont actually give you Roster stars, but still give XP.-Some enemies can see troops while the troops can't see them WHEN they are right in front of him. ie around a corner or in a room he is facing.-No trooper will ever die if you use the restart button. Guy dies, restart mission and you have him back.Overall, Fun for the stradegy people out there and a very fine and playable game right now. 8/10

Posted: December 3, 2015
												Doorkickers in an awesome semi-realistic top-down pause/play Urban Ops tactical planning game (a lot of words, i know), focusing on police and counter-terrorism scenarios. It has exceptional value for your money, and the devs are decent enough to actually bring a good game out of early acces. That shouldn't have to be a plus, but it is.Your SWAT team is fully levlable with it's own skill tree, seperate from the leveling of each individual team member, and the unlocking of new gear for your team, which adds to the feeling of progression and depth of the game. There are a LOT of ways to complete most levels, and as you unlock new gear you can go back and solve a scenario in a new and better way, improving replayability. Your team members die permanently (and is replaced by a rookie police officer) if you don't restart a mission where someone died, which gives every tactical decission you make a distinct feeling of importance. For someone with basic experience with military urban ops tactics, gameplay feels intuitive and realistic in that real life techniques and equipment are successfull when applied apropriately within the game. It's rewarding that I can jump straight into the game, learn the controlls, and instantly see how a good plan works, and a bad plan don't, and know EXACTLY why.One of the few problems i have with the game (which is completely subjective, and perhaps even a part of the intended difficulty) is that as the maps become bigger and the enemies more numeorus it becomes VERY tedious to make a working plan beforehand, and you basically have to "test" your way through the level. Another problem I have is that it gets problematic to controll bigger teams when you want them to walk the same path but perform different actions and cover different sectors, because their waypoints and routes overlap and create an unmanagable cluster. There should be a better way to toggle between the units and finalize/hide certain units' actions (maybe there is, but i missed it?).Another thing I wish was improved is the intelligence and behviour of the AI enemies. Considering they are hardened terrorists and seasoned criminals they're pretty stupid. This is really a realism issue, and not a gameplay issue, as I do mostly enjoy the game and it's dificulty as it is.

Posted: January 13, 2015
												Doorkickers is a awesome game!  You have to plan and execute Missions for a Police Squad. You can plan the whole execution before you start the mission or change the plan while the Mission is running. You have many options how you get the job done. You get single Mission: They are like squad training missions. You can use them to learn and improve your Squad. Unlock new weapons and skills. You have multiple Campaigns: Here you have to be careful it is possible that your squad members die during the campaign.There is also new contet, which is added to the game constantly from the developers. In Addtion, you have content from players on the Steam workshop. Overall, you can have a lot of fun with that game. I bought it on the Steam Christmas sale but form me is worth it´s 19, - €

Posted: February 6, 2015
												This game is a completely hidden gem. The content is massive and it's completely unassuming. I have been fooled by the top down 2D'ness of the game. Yet behind that facade of what might seem like a "cheap" game, are 3 campaigns, *80* (yes, EIGHTY) single missions with a variety of modes like 'Terrorist Hunt', 'Hostage Rescue', and a random mission generator to boot. Not only that, player made custom missions can be downloaded through the workshop.A variety of equipment are available, and it's extremely realistic. The added fact that all rifles are fired on single shot merrits mentioning, as firing assault rifles on full auto are only in movies or untrained armies. This game in my opinion, is far better than SWAT 4 or even the original Rainbow Six series were.

Posted: February 8, 2016
												Edit: Apparantly there is an android version - it just isn't available for MY android units, unfortunately. Rating: 8/10Replayability: HighBudget: Too expensive - Once it drops to about 5 Eur, I recommend getting it. Lenght: Endless. This entertaining little title isn't a full game with a story and such. It's an entertaining small game with good functions and a cheap setup, that works really well as a minor entertainment module on a tablet - It's a wonder it's not out for android yet! This could even feasibly be played on a phone. It's a really fun game, especially for people who enjoy games like Rainbow Six, SWAT, Xcom or the old Commandos series. I'd say the game has less depth than the goldie-oldies like Commandos, and it appears to have no multiplayer function, which could have been interesting - You know, sort of co-op, each player controls half the available team and can see each other's plans. Watch a let's play of this title before you get it! I wouldn't say this is a game you're going to binge-play, nor is it a game you will play occupationally, but it's good to have on a windows tablet or light-end laptop for train rides, plane rides, killing time in lunchbreaks or what not. If you have an Ipad (I don't), the game will serve you much better - I hope it comes out for android too, as it would become much more usable for people in general. It's sort of the same "type" (not to confuse with genre) as FTL, the sort of game that has a lot of entertainment value without really having any real depht. I find that I enjoy these minimalistic games a lot.

Posted: March 12, 2016
												The store page description said it clear: Real Time with Free Pause No turns, no hexes, no action points or awkward interfaces Realistic but action packed Those points made me buy the game, and I was never disappointed. Door Kickers is best SWAT type tactical strategy you will ever play. The game offers many customization for your squad, many type of weapons and tools to choose from. There are tons of missions and campaigns, with ability to build your own mission and share it on steamwrokshop. The main things that made me really enjoy this game is the planning, the more you plan and make sure you use the right tools in right position the more of chance you will pass the mission, the beautiful thing that once you hit the unpause button you will see how your orchestrated plan going, and if it works as you plan and succeed, you will feel the satisfaction in such way that you will never feel it in any other similar game. The game use simple 2D graphics, but with many details to reload and recoil of each weapon.I totally recommend this game for any tactical games fans, it is great value of money.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												very easy to learn as the controls are quite simple, but quite an in depth game thats highly addictive.one thing i really love about this game is that it takes about 3 seconds to load to the main menu, after which everything instantly loads the second you click it. that means i can load up and be straight into it within a very quick amount of time.drawing a path for your team to follow is quite fluid, if your wobbly on the mouse your teams path will be too.insert commands easily onto that path, so they will CLEAR !  a room before moving on, strafe a certain direction, or wait for a go code.use the single missions to level up your team, unlock better weapons, shields, armor, tools etc by earning stars. once something is unlocked its free to assign to any other team member.once your team is good enough you can start doing campaigns.theres virtually hundreds of maps to choose from, and a steam workshop to add even more gear and maps.unlock new squad types like assaulter, breacher, shield and improve them by earning doctrine points to spend on perks for each class.weapon type and loadout will have a big effect on how your team maneuvers, its fire rate, accuracy, stopping power or clip size.assaulting an airplane to save some hostages? maybe the pistols will allow you to maneuver around easier and change targets quicker to fire off a few well placed rounds rather than trying to use a clumsy shotgun or spray machine gun fire about.use a camera under the door to spot targets, blow open the door, flashbang, give the go signal with a "go code" to assault rooms full of terrorists from different doorways, save the hostages, disarm bombs, and taze the guy you have a warrant for.i give it 80/100 dead terrorists

												It's awesome. "Overwhelmingly positive" not only says it all but is dead-on.It feels not new but completely novel at the same time. I thought it'd finally be a game where you can just click play and enjoy it in between busy times (which you can) but so far it's only addictive and I can't stop playing.Planing out your raids, trying to get every little detail right, every little corner of the room covered is just heaps of fun. And I'm not even at the level yet where I would try to get the challenges done or challenge myself. It feels like one of those games where you keep thinking "yes, finally someone realized that graphics isn't all and gameplay is the important part of a game". If there are any glitches or graphics aren't good (it feels like they are just amazing enough for this game) than I haven't realized any of that because I'm completely sucked into the window in the middle of the screen where all the action is happening.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												In my years of gaming, I have seen many great products come and go. Great products like Rainbow Six and SWAT as they made their mark in the gaming world. You tend to look back on those games and ask yourself this question. Does anyone still remember those days? How they helped pave the way for tactical strategy in games?When Door Kickers came along, the answer couldn't have been more clear. "♥♥♥♥ yeah we remember!" What's good about the game:-The deep tactical planning, choose from a wide variety of weapons and equipment to plan your approach. (You can even change their names if you're into that sort of thing.) Use your troopers to their maxium potiental to get the job done and bring everyone home safe. Espically in Iron Man mode you will have to take your planning very seriously as every  trooper death only makes your job harder.  -Open-ended planning, missions can be completed in several different ways. It will be up to you to determine what is the best course of action. -Random enemy placement. In most if not all cases, the odds will be stacked against you. You will face off against several tangos (bad guys) armed to the teeth and not knowing for sure of how many  are there or their location adds tenson to the action. Just because you have a plan figured out, doesn't mean things can't go wrong. -The ability to do two different playstyles. The first being a pause, plan, action playstyle. Before your troopers get into the thick of it, you can pause the game and develop a course of action for them. Tell who to go where, where to look, where to strafe, etc. Then watch it unfold when you switch it to real time. The second being what I call wing-it mode. You can play the entire mission in real time and make things up as you go. So players that aren't into the whole stop and think style aren't forced to play that way. -Numerous amount of missions and counting. There are several missions to be completed in this game, all of which have a lot of replayablity to them. Single missions, campagns, custom player-made missions, randomly generated missions. It feels practically endless to what can be done to have missions.  Furthermore, as of the time of this review, the developers are still adding missions, content, and improvements to the game.-Mod support. Something about the game you want to change up? Things like new weapons, gear,etc? Odds are there is a mod that fits the bill and there are quite a few to choose from. -The bits of comedic relief. Though this game has an overall serious tone, there are bits of humor thrown in that is quite amusing to lighten the mood a little when needed. It's not obnoxious or intrusive ethier, it's well timed and unexpected.  I'm not to going to spoil them as I'll leave them to be discovered yourself. ;)I honestly can't think of anything serious to complain about with Door Kickers. It's an overall well made and addicting tactical strategy game that is worthy of your money and time.  Even at full price, you get a lot for twenty dollars.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
*** I bought this game during the 2014 year-end Steam sale, and played when I got back to my uni before the finals week, most of the time off-line (>80% of my playtime) due to a massive flood disaster. So at the time this is written, I have played almost 100 hours offline, and only 13 hours with Steam online, which is why Steam only clocks me as have played only 13 hours.Oh and one more thing: I like writing, so my review is going to be REALLY long.Now with that out of the way, I'm going to get to reviewing Door Kickers (DK).What is Door Kickers?You know what Rainbow Six (R6) is? If you don't, scroll down to the bottom of my review where I tell you a bit about R6. If you do, well, that's what DK is, except for three differences: DK is a top-down tactical shooter / R6 is an FPS tactical shooter DK is very easy and light to just pick up and play, whenever, wherever. Coffee break, lunch hour, taking a sh*t (if there will ever be a tablet version, which is very much possible if the dev bothers), doing your whatever thing with your laptop at Starbucks, etc. DK has you control a SWAT team with a considerably wide range of Law Enforcement Organization (LEO)-level gear / R6 has you control a bunch of hardened and specialized team of tacticool genius-level operator dudes and chicks bearing a very-wide range of military-grade toysThat's it. The rest, everything you remember from your fondest R6 days - choosing, equipping and leveling up your squads (with different classes), breach gadgets, planning your maneuvers, your button-hooks, wedges/pies, rescuing hostages, defusing bombs, capturing HVTs, retrieving intel/evidence, or straight-up delivering 'Merica to the bad guys - it's all there, AND THEN SOME: "Doctrine" system - a set of RPG-like skill trees, each specializing in different weapons and engagement discipline. DK is constantly updated with new contents such as campaigns and maps by both the devs and the awesomely capable community. DK has loads of awesome mods in the workshop. ATM there are: an R6-themed sound overhaul, loads of new military-grade weapons and operator skins for those who want a change in atmosphere, and tons of custom maps designed by the community. DK lets you watch a replay of your mission, record it with a built-in recorder, and even choose a point from your replay, and re-do the mission from said point. LEVEL EDITOR - need I say more?So, with the basic features explained, what are the pros and cons?PROS: A mix of casual and hardcore: play how you want - easy-breezy, smash and shoot your way into the sh*t (which will most likely get your team or the hostage killed), OR take your time with recon (slow is smooth, smooth is fast), OR a mix of both (scout a bit, get in and improvise as necessary). Like R6, watching the result of your hardly-worked planning go down (especially when it goes right), like when your team is smoothly moving in, covering every angle, or when they smash in hard and fast and smack the bad guys who's having their thumbs up their behind, is simply indescribable. Config files are easy to manipulate, which lets you alter the in-game assets (weapons stats and attributes etc.) to your preference, also makes modding easier Replay feature Considerable replayability Awesome community-made contents Devs that DELIVARRRRSCONS: MIGHT get boring once you've aced all the maps and campaigns, and have run out of custom contents to play around with, but that's a given with any single-player games. Last I checked, the replay feature is still a little imperfect, where it sometimes "desyncs" and fail to play to the end. IMHO the breaching features can still be polished, in terms of set-pieces, such as a more snappy flash-entry or frag-entry. Not enough non-lethal options: so far there's only the taser-gun, but the workshop is quick to remedy this by offering a wide array of community-made non-lethal options (the super-painful-non-lethal-but-I-might-as-well-be-dead-if-I-get-shot-with-this bean bag rounds, rubber/silicone bullets, etc.)So, do you recommend it?Does the leader of a popular religion defecate in remote areas of the forest?11/10 as far am I'm concerned, and I'm not even kidding.What in the hell is R6?You see, most of you who are below 20 most probably haven't heard of the R6 series, apart from the Vegas installments which are NOT what R6 really is. R6 is a hardcore tactical shooter where you control a team of counter-terrorist squad during various tactically-demanding operations, be it recon, seek & destroy, search & rescue, and bomb defusal. The R6 initiative, a fictional covert counter-terrorist organization born from the mind of the great Tom Clancy (a great, great author, despite the heavy political bias in his novels), specializes in going where the regular LEO can't go or has been terribly outmatched, where a swift and precise tactical intervention is severely needed, and where the faintest of the slightest hint of NATO involvement will stir up some real sh*t, so even the most specialest and tacticoolest of operators can't go. Oh, wait, that last bit is Splinter Cell. Sorry.You see, at least as far as I understand from my various encounter with Hollywood pop-culture, there are a few levels of domestic LEO, which deals in different levels of criminal situations: Some drunk guy smacked his loud-mouthed wife about? You send out a dispatch so the local PD on his beat will go in and check it out. Convenience store in a stick-up? Local PD. A junkie with an illegal 9mm he got from Motherf*cker Jones is holding his neighbor for ransom because he can't afford his fix? You might wanna call the SWAT to back the local PD up, just in case it really gets out of hand. Local gang drinking party turned into a violent shootout because of a domestic disturbance warrant serve turned a little too serious? A homosexual man and his totally straight crew decides to rob a sleepy bank, but it turned into a messy hostage situation? Definitely call in the SWAT, AND the FBI HRT. A maniacal cartel kingpin from across the border decides that the Narc, ATF and/or Feds have been too nosy and destroyed too much of their business decides to send a hit squad and shoot up a local PD HQ? An extremist militant cell rounded up and locked in a huge bunch of civs in a big library and set-off a timed dirty bomb in it? The UN conference was smashed in and every world leader is held hostage with demands of the US to hand over all their nukes? THESE, you call in the R6. Except for the last part with the UN? Yeah that's definitely Ghost Recon turf.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												S.W.A.T. meets the original Rainbow Six planning interface with a plethora of missions, agents, weapons and achievements to keep the hungriest tactical fanatic engaged.  This game surprised me in how well it captures tactical close quarters combat in urban environments with such a simple yet effective presentation / UI.  The graphics are detailed and communicate a sense of realism without trying to be photorealistic.But where the game really shines is in the depth of strategy that is involved in developing a plan and executing it with flawless precision.  The only thing that gives that a run for its money is when things go horribly wrong and you still manage to salvage the mission through quick thinking, dumb blind luck and grit.  Rarely do you feel like you "got away" with something due to A.I. glitches which further elevates the feeling of success when you pull of a great plan.If you like strategy games do yourself a favour and give this one a go.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												(To preface, this was originally written as a not-recommended and has changed back and forth many times. My thoughts are still exactly the same, but my tolerance of the problems has increased a little bit as time goes on. Take from that what you will.)If I could give this game a "Neutral" rather than a "Recommended", I would do that instead.This game has a lot of strong pros and a lot of strong cons. I'd recommend reading the details to determine if the game is for you rather than taking the recommend at face value!So the best way I can describe this game is if you take Frozen Synapse and SWAT (4, not 3) and combine them into a game with quick objectives and short but satisfying levels. You'll be tasked to take your organized team, breach and enter various locations, and complete various objectives such as neutralizing terrorists, rescuing hostages, retreiving evidence, and such.You can either choose to plan out your assault completely from the start and play it out, or you can organize it in chunks with a handy pause function. Pausing makes the game a bit easier but making a single plan can be very rewarding.The game has a mission generator (which is less of a generator since it basically grabs a random mission layout and randomizes the enemy and objective layout). There's a lot of content here for you to keep playing, granted you don't mind having a limited amount of variety in the way of objectives and how you handle them (which is not a bad thing since that's a lot how real scenarios play out - like the book).Real life tactics can come into handy play here minus a few key ideas such as leaning- though I'm not sure how it would work given its control scheme......Which is where the problems start to become evident.You see, the way you set a path for your SWAT members to follow is you click and drag them one. In order to place actions along the path, you create nodes on it by right clicking. This makes sense in theory but it has several hangups which severly ruin the flow. Rather than having to delete parts of your path manually to change them, you just pick a part earlier and draw from there which will erase everything that comes after that spot. Unfortunately, it's very easy to do this by accident and the game lacks any sort of undo functionality. This can result in you spending upwards to 5 - 10 minutes making an intricate path only to accidentally change the wrong team member's path or mis click, wasting your time having to redo it.The game also has a large auto-snap when highlighting notes, making precision very difficilt. If you have multiple teammates on a similar path with each of their nodes next to each other, the game turns into a frustrating pixel hunt trying to get the correct officer in the correct part of the path.The game also has some problematic design choices that clash with the subject matter. Namely that the game wants to you play very fast score wise (and some missions require you to be fast with as quick as a 10 second or less time limit for hostages) yet actively discourages fast playing with realistic health and mobility stats that change with weaponry and body armor. In order to get 3 stars for the mission, one of the requirements is to beat a certain time. This wouldn't be a problem but these times are very unforgiving, often forcing you to ignore your officer's safety in favor of working very quickly. Often you'll find that you won't have time use a spy camera or silently pick a lock as you'll compromise your score.Now, if score was only for personal gratification and leaderboards, I wouldn't have a problem with this design. However, you use the stars that you unlock in order to purchase other weapons, body armor, and tools. If you're earning less stars per mission, you're going to progress a bit slower.The progression itself isn't terribly slow, but it also feels like a system that's designed to limit the players' toolsets rather than give them options. It's restrictive and ultimately pointless as a lot of unlockables aren't worth it compared to the superior options. What you'll most likely do (and a lot of players also recommend this) is to find an easy generated mission and grind it until you have all the stars you need to unlock what you want. You won't be doing it for long, as unlocked items are unlocked for everybody (as opposed to per officer), I feel like this artificially extends playtime rather than actively engaging the player. This could have been done better. It's not a dealbreaker but it's also needlessly frustrating for the first one or two hours of play.This isn't to suggest that the game is bad, however. Like I already said, if I could give this game a Neutral rating, I would.While I didn't experiment much with it, the game has a really neat campaign mode where officers that are killed during missions are permenently dead. Since you also train your officers as part of the progression system, this can make for a really interesting dynamic where you need to take the risk of sending in your best trained officers to deal with a mission but have the possibility of losing them, or sending in worse officers at the risk of performing the mission not as well. It's not terribly fleshed out, but it's still interesting.The game can also be really satisfying when you're not fighting the mechanics or design choices. It's a really strong idea and it works well enough, but some of the execution falls a bit flat.If it sounds like these things wouldn't bother you much or you're willing to look past them, then by all means pick this game up- as there is a lot of fun to be had here. However, if you think these will bother you, then either wait until this game is on sale or wait for Door Kickers 2. Apparently some issues may be fixed there and I think it's worth keeping note of.Hopefully this helped! And yes, I know this review will have a very low number of votes because people downvote most negative reviews for whatever reason. So thanks for reading if you got this far!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												I consider this game a spiritual successor to the original Rainbow Six titles. You select your roster, change their loadouts for the mission, plan their points of entry and the paths they'll take during the mission, then you watch it all come to life. If you're quick enough, you can change your squad members' tactics on the fly in real-time, or you can just pause the action and make your adjustments from there. All in all, this game feels very good and it's easy to lose hours retrying one mission just to make it come out perfectly.Unlike Rainbow Six, you actually have to unlock all of the different weapons and specializations which gives the game a bit of an RPG feel, if not a bit frustrating for people who immediately want to use an assault rifle. There's multiple stock campaigns, and a good amount of user-created content as well. If you're looking for a true spiritual successor to OG R6, and are willing to settle for top-down graphics, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												During a 50% off sale, the dev Vulpe told me this game was worth more than £7, and that it was the cheapest it was going to be. I quote him directly: "The game will not be discounted lower than 50%". I like to think of myself as a generous man, but his comment on the price not going any lower only brought out my love and desire to take on a challenge. The waiting game began. Months and months passed, and the summer sale had begun. I see Door Kickers with a 60% off tag, but my excitement is contained. Not even a grin or smirk is shown. I wasn't going to give in this easily. It's 3 minutes until the new daily and flash sales begin. I refresh the Steam store at 6PM on the dot. I browse the deals, and to my disappointment, Door Kickers has not been discounted further. A week passes and the 60% is still there.  Not a single daily or flash has contained this game. My mind is filled with Vulpe's manic laughter, I hallucinate him & Gabe knocking at my door. I have nightmares where they tear my wallet from my pants and spend all my money gifting Door Kickers to people I'm not even friends with. I want to take the plunge, but my instinct tells me it isn't over yet. I've been sitting at my computer for 4 days straight now. Just waiting for new sales, refreshing over and over. I haven't slept. I haven't eaten. It's 6AM. I refresh the store for the morning flash sale. There it is. Door Kickers, 75% off. I sit in silence at first. I feel relief, and I feel pain. A tear falls down my cheek, and I click add to cart. I pay £3.75 and the game is mine. I sit back in my chair as the game installs, and laugh like I've lost my mind. I did it, I thought to myself. I persevered and reaped the rewards.I'm 3 hours into the game, and I start crying. Vulpe, you were right; I can confirm this game is worth more than £7. Thank you for this emotional journey. Well played, Vulpe. Well played.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Great "simple" tacticool title, albeit with some minor scuffs.The game mechanics are VERY easy to learn, yet surprisingly complex, so you can easily get into the game quickly, but will be working for a LONG time to master the game. And yes, this is one of those games where you will WANT to 3 star a level. So, while the levels themselves aren't super diverse(some are, but most aren't), you will want to keep re-attempting them for that perfect run(ala R6).The game definitely has some small issues still though, but ALL of these could be patched easily:* still hard to properly orient your guys throughout the process. Yes, there are "two" modes of look direction(strafe + body facing), but the game doesn't seem to always follow what you have selected(sometimes you'll find your guys walking backwards into a room...)* still issues with "overlapping" unit movement and proper selection. ie: if unit A and unit B are traveling close together...it's VERY hard to select A and orient him; oftentimes the game will make it hard to select A or B, so I would recommend a way to "dim" or outright remove other unit pathing temporarily during the setup process to avoid this* randomness(a good thing and a bad thing): there are times when you'll just do the SIMPLEST layout(with no facing setup) and it will be flawless...other times you'll put lots of effort into a perfect run...only to see your "elite" soldier stand in a doorway and eat a magazine dump...* some of the weapon options/classes are kind of pointless. Outside of a maybe 1-2 missions...there just isn't any use for the shield class. Same thing for weapons: there are a couple that are CLEAR standouts in their grouping...and you'll be using them 99% of the time...so yea...sucks for the rest of them* "silent" mode is still buggy. Too many times you'll have your guys barge into a room and not fire, even when hostages/team members are in immediate danger, all the while...you have to press the "fire" button to give them permission(or at least override their behavior). Sometimes they work right, sometimes they don't. Kinda weird. Some kind of ROE options would be nice here or another planning option to let them override silent mode for a specific walk* $20 price point is IMO a little steep for what it offers. The devs are awesome and they have been consistent with updates so far, so it's worth rewarding them for the time I've put into it. For a new player, I'd think $15 would be more the sweetspot(check out Steam sales later in the year).tl;dr: The game boils down to attempting to perfect missions, ala R6. The base mechanics are easy enough to learn, but you will spend a fair amount of time retrying missions until things click together.See these webm videos for further evidence of how great this game is:http://a.pomf.se/jwkctw.webmhttp://a.pomf.se/wmpprv.webm

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Doorkickers is a fun, challenging shooting puzzle game with a tactical paintjob and some forgetable RPG elements. Let me start by saying that Door Kickers is not what I really hoped it to be: a spiritual successor to the Swat line of games. Remember those? They were the counter to most shooting games because you could get the best victory with the fewest shots fired. A careful and well-planned approach was more useful than  running and gunning. Being cautious was almost always better than being fast. Door kickers has none of that. The goal is generally to kill everyone besides your team that has a gun on the map. DK isn't a police simulator or even that much of a tactical simulator (for reasons I'll go into below)- it's a puzzle game. But it's fun and I found it delivered plenty. In general DK wants you to complete the mission without losing any of your guys and in the shortest time possible. This usually means killing all suspects but you're also tasked with preventing the execution of hostages and demolition of bombs. Keep in mind not only are the suspects absurdly numerous but they throw grenades at your guys. Yeah. There are also some extra goals for each mission, like using a single trooper, not pausing, or using only one plan. These are sometimes neat little challenges but other times are frustrating or, sometimes, impossible due to the design of the mission (some impossible challenges have been removed in patches, I suspect more will be later). As I said there's not much cautiousness allowed if you want the full score for a mission. Instead you go in fast and if it doesn't work, just restart and try again. Repeat until you succeed below the time limit. It seems the newly added campaign missions are a little less strict for time. You can build your squad but there's not much individualism there. You can put backer's names and faces in to personalize a trooper but that's it: no backstories, special skilles, interactions, etc. Fans of Jagged Allience (or to some degree Swat 2) shouldn't expect much here. Troopers advance in 3 skills as they go along but I honestly can't tell much of a difference between an expert and novice trooper. You can gain your whole squad certain skills\upgrades which are sometimes useful but many are bizarre in that they replicate what should be normal behavior. For example: being able to hold fire when not under threat. Given the micromanagement elsewhere I don't see why it's even an upgrade instead of an inate ability. It's really tiring to be trying to do a stealthy approach and the guy you've armed with a carbine decides to blow away an enemy across the map who has no idea what's going on, thereby alerting everyone. The "skill" in question would also be much more useful if it were a toggle rather than the way it is implemented as a button that must be pressed every time one wants to fire. I'm also not sure how a squad needs to "learn" how to open doors instead of noisily kicking them. I've tried both, and opening a door is easier and more tactically sound!There are lots of guns and devices. Most are redundent and add little but it's nice to have some variety. Some of the weapon stats are very unrealistic. It seems that a .45 caliber pistol is easily more powerful ('stopping power') than a UMP45, which is basically the very same cartridge in a longer barrel and therefore more velocity. Looking at the stats it might even be more powerful than a assault rifle! It doesn't make any sense and I'm not sure if it's as a 'balance' issue or rule of cool. There really is no arresting necessary, except for those missions that present unarmed subjects specifically targeted for arrest. Nor is it easy to arrest suspects, as they never voluntarily drop their weapons and the troopers don't give them a chance to do so anyway. The only real way I've found to arrest armed suspects is to tase them and then cuff them while they are disabled. This is a tricky and very risky move when there's more than one suspect around and there's really no reason to do it since putting a bullet through someone leads to the same result.   The enemy AI is pretty dumb. There's a mod to leave dead bodies on the ground instead of having them vanish and I think I know why it is not the default... it looks absurd how many bodies will be lying in the same spot. You'd think once you kill the first 3 guys who walk out a door there would be a change in tactics. That would be a mistake. By all means, keep shooting them as they march out as if they're cattle. The only thing stopping you is the need to occasionally change magazines (from your unlimited supply) and the time ticking away. But on later missions the poor AI is hidden with absolutely STUPID levels of armor for the enemies who, while still dumb, will manage to murder your troopers immediately upon seeing them from 150 yards away.♥♥♥♥♥♥ why don't we hire these criminals? They're vastly better than anything the good guys can do. Plus they never have to reload (had a guy firing a shotgun at me for 2 minutes without pause). Friendly AI is also robotic (the only thing giving the bad guys a fighting chance in addition to their absurd numbers and lots of access points). You need to micromanage everything if you want to get a good result, to the extent where you need to manually direct the troopers in a 'slicing pie' movement to clear a doorway (otherwise they'll tend to sorta just charge in and promptly get shot). Troopers will respond to being shot... eventually... but that seems to be the only stimulus that will get their attention. They seem to be of two minds as to whether they'll address a threat in an area not specifically designated as 'their' cover zone. Usually this means they'll ignore it if it's important and engage it like flies on♥♥♥♥♥♥if it's NOT important. So if there's two bad guys and one is disco dancing while the other is moving to shoot the hostage, it seems like the troopers go for the dancer. Well, okay, can't blame them for that, but I wish there was a way to designate a target out of several visible. So if it sounds like I'm negative about this game, it's just because I wanted something a little more like Swat 2. But the game is addictive and if you buy it knowing you're getting a tacticalish puzzle shooter you can have a lot of fun. It's nice to play things out in slow motion and the RT\Pause action works quite well (on single story buildings). Watching the replay afterwards can be fun as it brings everything together. The dev-team seems responsive to the community and there is modding (as well as a mission editor). It strikes me as one of those games that just demands 'one more try' even when you should probably be out mowing the lawn. I believe I paid $15 for the early access and that seems to me to be a good price-point for the game.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												For those who have struggle systems and wish they could cop Rainbow Six: Siege, Door Kickers is more than just an adequate substitute; it is a tactical game worthy of play and praise on its own terms. KillHouse Games has done its homework in terms of researching the qualities of guns such as the P90, the Benelli M4 (Joint Service Combat Shotgun), Tarvor, SAR-21 and more. This research extends to considering factors such as cornering with large weapons and reload speeds. For those looking for a good tactics game, they need not look farther than Door Kickers.Full Review at Geeks Under Grace	[www.geeksundergrace.com]

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												For those who have struggle systems and wish they could cop Rainbow Six: Siege, Door Kickers is more than just an adequate substitute; it is a tactical game worthy of play and praise on its own terms. KillHouse Games has done its homework in terms of researching the qualities of guns such as the P90, the Benelli M4 (Joint Service Combat Shotgun), Tarvor, SAR-21 and more. This research extends to considering factors such as cornering with large weapons and reload speeds. For those looking for a good tactics game, they need not look farther than Door Kickers.Full Review at Geeks Under Grace	[www.geeksundergrace.com]

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Great "simple" tacticool title, albeit with some minor scuffs.The game mechanics are VERY easy to learn, yet surprisingly complex, so you can easily get into the game quickly, but will be working for a LONG time to master the game. And yes, this is one of those games where you will WANT to 3 star a level. So, while the levels themselves aren't super diverse(some are, but most aren't), you will want to keep re-attempting them for that perfect run(ala R6).The game definitely has some small issues still though, but ALL of these could be patched easily:* still hard to properly orient your guys throughout the process. Yes, there are "two" modes of look direction(strafe + body facing), but the game doesn't seem to always follow what you have selected(sometimes you'll find your guys walking backwards into a room...)* still issues with "overlapping" unit movement and proper selection. ie: if unit A and unit B are traveling close together...it's VERY hard to select A and orient him; oftentimes the game will make it hard to select A or B, so I would recommend a way to "dim" or outright remove other unit pathing temporarily during the setup process to avoid this* randomness(a good thing and a bad thing): there are times when you'll just do the SIMPLEST layout(with no facing setup) and it will be flawless...other times you'll put lots of effort into a perfect run...only to see your "elite" soldier stand in a doorway and eat a magazine dump...* some of the weapon options/classes are kind of pointless. Outside of a maybe 1-2 missions...there just isn't any use for the shield class. Same thing for weapons: there are a couple that are CLEAR standouts in their grouping...and you'll be using them 99% of the time...so yea...sucks for the rest of them* "silent" mode is still buggy. Too many times you'll have your guys barge into a room and not fire, even when hostages/team members are in immediate danger, all the while...you have to press the "fire" button to give them permission(or at least override their behavior). Sometimes they work right, sometimes they don't. Kinda weird. Some kind of ROE options would be nice here or another planning option to let them override silent mode for a specific walk* $20 price point is IMO a little steep for what it offers. The devs are awesome and they have been consistent with updates so far, so it's worth rewarding them for the time I've put into it. For a new player, I'd think $15 would be more the sweetspot(check out Steam sales later in the year).tl;dr: The game boils down to attempting to perfect missions, ala R6. The base mechanics are easy enough to learn, but you will spend a fair amount of time retrying missions until things click together.See these webm videos for further evidence of how great this game is:http://a.pomf.se/jwkctw.webmhttp://a.pomf.se/wmpprv.webm

content:
Posted: January 3
												Let's start saying I like this game. It's fun, there's different ways to get to every objective, lots of tactics involved.You need luck too, but that's just a minor thing, and it makes things even more realistic.Graphics are nicely done, sound could be better (so... my "Angela" has a male voice?) but it's good enough, maybe a few more character customization options would be nice.HOWEVER, there are two things that prevent me from recommending the game.BUGSI've just completed the "Cartel Beach Party" mission, it took me about an hour to get three stars in it. That's because the plan I was using (which is the one I think is best to accomplish this goal) relied pretty heavily in having two shields and two assaulters, with shields opening the doors to small rooms while assaulters had to flashbang and then kill the guys in the bigger areas, plus the final shootout in the living room. The problems here are four:1. Shields ALWAYS turn their back to a door while opening it, getting hit AT LEAST once each time.2. Shields sometime go through the doors before opening them, exposing themselves to enemy fire.3. Enemies can sometimes shoot through walls if they're close to a unit.4. Units sometimes get stuck in front of doors with their guns lowered, exposing themselves to enemy fire and not reacting.This is far more than what I can stand, considering these bugs compromised my mission to the point I had to restart it 20+ times to get lucky enough not to get hit.STARSThe Stars system is beyond frustrating. You get X stars based on how many stars you get in a mission, and they only count once (unless you get a higher rank, in that case the latest obtained stars are added). With items costing 10+ stars, and with stars being non-farmable, a poor equipment choice will doom your missions to failure.I got 3 stars on almost every mission up to the first rescue missions, and (probably) wasted my stars in not-so-good equipment. Now, I can still progress in the game, but I think my units would last longer with, say, a better armor.They really need to change the Stars to something new, or at least make them farmable.In the very end, it's a shame this game has these two problems. Other than that, it's a great game.

												A quick summary of a mission plan in this game.-Tactic works properly checking every corner and eliminating everyone in each room without setting foot inside.Killed a hostage-Second try you try to engage at distanceSomebody's in the room behind you-You have one guy watch the room while the other shootsEntry fails when your flashbang bounces off an enemy-You remake your entire team for assault and recon so recon check every room, extract hostages and lay down explosives for the assaults as well as collecting evidence, the assaults go in, set off the explosives, rescue any missed hostages and complete any remaining objectives. Plan for use works perfectly.Assault killed when a charge backfires and a terrorist comes out of the lavoratory. Recon die later to heavy fire.-You send one guy in, randomly with a shotgunMission complete in 20 seconds.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Do you like a tactical shooter? That requires you to think, plan, and rapidly respond to situations? If not, then you might as well leave. If you try to run and gun your entire squad will die in no less than 5-10 seconds (I wish I was joking), This game is brutal, but it is so rewarding when you win without losing  a single squad member, and it's a helluva lotta fun getting there. Bottom line is that this game is incredible, but it depends on what type of game you like. If you're the Call of Duty, run and gun player this game isn't for you. If you're the Arma II, tactical shooter who likes stratgey, this game is a must buy. it's so much fun and best of all, it's constantly being updated! Honestly, get this game!

Early Access Review
								This game is absolutely fantastic. It is really engaging, features character customization and REALLY makes you think about your next move. It is very fluid and the controls are well made and simple to use, featuring real time strategy.Despite it being Early Access, this game feels very clean and finished. You have to clear rooms and save hostages, take out all the enemies and defuse bombs.The one and ONLY gripe I have is just the way the room clearing works. The game ends when you have killed all terrorists, even if you haven't cleared the other rooms. Personally, this slightly ruins the immersion for me and it would be great if the developers could fix this.Brilliant game and well worth the price. 9/10 :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Bought this game quite recently, but already I love it. It's a great overhead 2D game where you control a SWAT team and have to command them tactically through hostile situations. Here's a quick overview:PROS(+++) Mission Variety -- There are many types of missions: there are "clear all hostiles" missions, hostage rescues, domb defusal, arrests, friendly escorts, and even a mode where you must collect evidence before criminals destory it. The game has plenty of "official missions", which are pre-rendered maps with variations of these missions; you can play these many times to improve your results and earn medals. It also has campaigns, which make the injuries and deaths on your squad have permanence and require you to safely lead your men through each mission. Most importantly, however, is the random mission generator, which picks maps at random and assigns varying scenarios and missions, or genreates maps for you to clear; this is especially fun when you set the genration options to random and aren't sure what you'll get in terms of enemy strength. Finally, there is a map editor and the ability to download other people's maps, and with the devs themselves adding new missions and campaigns as the game goes on, the challenges won't likely run out anytime soon.(++) Squad Scaling -- Throwing a little RPG into the mix, the game provides you with experience -- both for each trooper and the squad as a whole -- after each mission. These can be used to unlock skills for the whole squad, and each trooper will increase their own stats as you use them. You also unlock more weapons and equipment as you earn stars for completing missions quickly and without losing men, and its fun to level and gear up as you beat more and more missions, making armored or armed enemeies easier to handle.(++) Enjoyable gameplay -- The enemy varieties and randomness in each mission gives each scenario a freshness, and requires you to keep thinking through encounters instead of just doing the same thing over and over (although the restart button is there when you need it). It's a great experience if you've ever wanted to command a SWAT team and hear them shout "Clear! Clear!" as they systematically put bullets into hostiles.CONS(-) Controls/Interface -- Once you get used to them, the path-drawing/command-giving controls are fairly intuitive and work 90% of the time. However, as I've found with a few top-down tactics games, you don't always get the full level of control you'd want when working with your men. In certain cases, such as when two trooper's paths overlap or giving orders that stack commands on door opening, you'll misclick and put your shotgunner in front of your riot shielder or send a man through a door backwards. There are a few things the interface could do to alleviate this (such as perhaps showing unit paths one at a time, or giving a little more control over what order door opening actions are performed in) but overall it is a minor problem that usually causes little trouble once you know what to watch for.(-) Squad Scaling -- I know this was under PROS as well, but I found that my squad was fully trained and upgraded with the gear I wanted after only a few hours of gameplay. The rest of the upgrades, then, just felt like I was unlocking gear for the sake of using up my XP or stars, and now, though I still enjoy the missions, I've run out of things to unlock. Perhaps adding more unlockables or more squad skill trees would help keep advancement fresh as the game is played longer, though the focus of this game is on individual tactical missions and not squad progression.OVERALLIf you ever dreamed of virtually barking tactical decisions over radio to a SWAT team engaging hostiles, get this game. Hours of fun for sure.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												This is without doubt one of the best tactical games I've played in a long time. This is the kind of game that the PC was made for and thrives on. It reminds me of a perticular title I played way back when on the Amiga, called Eagles Nest, which was fantastic fun and was also top down. We older players appreciate this kind of game where thinking is a little more important than blasting, and when on the odd occasion I do get to play, its good to play a game like this. This game has made Christmas this year in particular very enjoyable and I can't rate it highly enough. If you like tactics and a game you can jump right into, and is not too taxing this is it.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
 NOTE: This review was last updated on 19 Dec, 2014 @ 4:49pm. Things I talked about may now be irrelevant. I will update this review in the near future as I have stopped progressively playing Doorkickers.As much as want to enjoy Door Kickers, as I am a big fan of Tactic RTS's , this one has given me the most frustation yet, and not in a good, challenging way either. Although my hours spent on this game at the time of this review is few, the movement mechanics have already hindered a positive impression from me. Often times, the fault in my plans is not in my ability, but in the broken mechanics of the game. When things work out and bugs such as shooting at the wall because the target is to my characters adjacent isn't a problem, the game is fun. Watching my team swiftly move in and clearing the area under a designated time feel rewarding and I can see what the dev's envision. But, having a constant struggle with things like redoing my carefully laid out plan because adding a step would somehow erase the previous ones, or, being unable to peak around the corner of a doorway because the action menu of breaching methods block my cursor from selecting my move node, breaks the experience for me. Among all my concerns however, the two big annoyances are when my team disregards the assigned command call (ex. Alpha, Bravo), and moves in on their own, and, when the units move before clearing a newly breached room. The work around for for the first issue is to redo my whole plan which, as mentioned before, is a chore that takes away from the fun. Although my review has mostly been negative, this is not a bad game at all. In fact, I would recommend you to give it as try as this review is soley based on my own critique. You may overlook these minor flaws and thoroughly enjoy this game. But for me, these minor issues were little details that became a major hassle as I played on.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												The game is quite fun, and there are some elements I'm excited about that are hard to find in other games. However, there are some serious flaws that made me not want to recommend this game.The biggest reason is the nonsense "progression system", squad leveling and classes. It simply doesn't make that you only start with pistols, but later, once you have "progressed", you can replay the missions with more and usually *better* equipment! It just makes the game easier and more boring faster. The classes determine what equipment can be used, and it's pretty arbitrary. For example,the point man class can only use pistols. That is, no SMGs(!) It seems the reason is because the pointman has to be fast. But come on, not even a small SMG? And the speed brings me to another point:Your 'troopers' walk at different speeds depending on their class and loadout. This makes sense, but it causes trouble; if you want to keep some formation while moving you will often find some of your troopers either running ahead of the others or lagging behind. According to the loading screen tips your troopers can shoot over each other's heads when in tight formation, but there's no way to know if you've achieved that. The speed difference / lack of proper formation also messes up timing.Synchronizing actions is a real hassle. You get four (4) 'go codes' which can be used for synchronizing actions. This is not enough! For example, if you want to stack up at a corner, throw a flashbang around it and then have your stack move out you will have to use two go codes: One for stacking up before your pointman throws the flashbang, and another to keep the rest of your stack moving out before the flashbang has been deployed.The planning editor is quite horrible. It's easy to make mistakes, and making changes is difficult or even impossible forcing you to delete potentially large parts of your plan.Lastly, I *really* hate when your troopers say "no tangos". It's too easy to misinterpret as "tangos"!! It's quite minor, but it's been driving me crazy.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												In most respects this is a fun, thoughtfully executed game but it is rendered almost unplayable because of the lack of an "undo" option. This lack, combined with the fact that it is very easy to accidentally delete the convoluted plans required to avoid pausing during levels, makes the planning phase of the game all too often an exercise in frustration. Until some kind of undo functionality is added into the game, I would not recommend it unless you want to play the levels in small chunks, pausing to issue orders every few seconds (thus removing most of the interest and challenge).

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												A lot of fun in Door Kickers comes from the failures.And unless you're endowed with the tactical genius of an Alexander the Great or Napoleon Bonaparte, you're going to fail a lot.Door Kickers is a top-down tactics game with an emphasis on positioning, planning, and reaction. The game tests your ability to adapt to unfavorable circumstances, and it often pits you against seemingly insurmountable odds in the form of armed thugs.All in all it's great fun. Feels very rewarding when you craft a plan for a particular mission and you pull it off successfully. Would urge you to wait for a sale though, as the base $20 price dropped down to just $4 in this past Autumn Sale.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								A very promising early access game. You control a swat team from a top down perspective, and command them. It plays like an rts but with a pause mechanic, so you can pause the game whenever you want, and take a look at your situation and issue commands. The game really feels complete already, it feels polished and is full of content. If you run out of vanilla content, it has steam workshop as well. Definitely worth the small asking price of $15. If you like forming a complex plan, and then watching it all play out, this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												This is honestly one of the most satisfying games I've played, and I honestly feel bad for not having more hours on it in comparison to my thousands on other games. (My problem is that I don't play single player games too extensively at all really...) THIS GAME, is amazing if you like tactical and rewarding engagements that YOU decide who wins not by reflexes, not by superior weaponry most of the time either but by playing, rather out-playing your contestants and manuevering to victory. Yes, this is a "Police" game but that's really only in the sense that you save hostages and stuff so most of it is really comparable to military operations in urban terrain which is some of the MOST demanding, tactically speaking, kind of operations. ANGLES are either your friend or your enemy depending on how you work them, teamwork among your units is imperative, and rewarding is it ever when you do a whole mission without losing a teammember or not getting shot due to methodical and tactical commanding on your part it's amazing!! This game is almost comparable to Counter Strike in the tactical sense of needing to use your equipment to gain an advantage over the naturally-advantageous defenders and then capitalize on gains you make into their whatever it may be at the given mission. In other words, this is the only game I've BOTHERED writing a review for so far so you KNOW it's seriously amazing given that right??!!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												I bought this thinking it would be similar to Frozen Synapse, but more recent version and a different flavour - police instead of highly abstract. It is similar but not as fun and much more frustrating.The main limitations I found which ruined the game for me were:1) It's very easy to accidentally mis-click and delete your entire plan - with no undo button... To Bad(TM)2) No way to add waypoints in the middle of paths - other than to redo everything3) No way to undo 'look this way' command other than lots of nodes (which isn't really a problem, except...)4) Nodes cannot be moved.I didn't play much because I kept accidentally deleting my plans. But, I did like the door breach methods and the RPG elements (buying weapons, levelling up guys). Never got round to the Campaign, because it's locked behind a level wall - can't play until level 6.I really wanted to like the game, but the utter frustration!!!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												The game gets repetitive really quickly. It felt like I was just shoving my team members straight into a meat grinder the entire time and I found it nearly impossible to complete any of the campaigns. There are some serious balancing issues, the game seems to feel and react as if the player is supposed to be a master tactician; every mission feels like you need to play through it until you're sick of it, and then some. I memorized several of the single mission maps just in order to beat them and properly plan everything out. I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone that's not a fan of extreme foreplanning and painstaking grinds.

content:
Posted: January 7
												It could be a great wtih a real planning system and AI.The planning is too arcade and confusionary for a real complex strategy; if it were like the first "Rainbow Six" series, it would be a 10/10. It's so lame that even the old "Commandos" is ten time better than this crappy thing.Also, more important, AI is very dumb. For example, entry men shoots straight to the tangos even with a hostage in between, killing him and making the mission fail stupidly. Or the same mission will end in a success or a fail depending on the mood of your troops: sometimes they see the enemy and shoot at it, other times they are blind and wait silently to be killed.Different weapons have controversial effects: the entry men kills better with a mp5 than a M4, even at long range. The stopping power and the balistics is not even taken in consideration.Enemies are in number of 20, you're in mission in 4, while in real entries attacking troops would be at least the same.I can never imagine how the community can write mostly positive reviews, seriously, you have real issues with tactical games: you accept all the crap that comes to the market only because is happy coloured and runs on iPad.Paid € 2,58 with a coupon, don't spend more on this♥♥♥♥♥♥Uninstalled after 5 hours of game.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Decent game, but definitely not very tactically deep, and certainly not very fun gameplay-wise. The gameplay itself boils down to mastering a room clearing technique, and once you figure this out, the game becomes very simple. Not much variety in the inventory, and frankly, once you unlock the Assault class, you have everything you need to beat the game outright. The RPG elements that are introduced are very shallow and don't really differentiate your squad members. The various roles in the squad are pretty superfluous, and at later stages, Assault is the only really valuable role you can take. Cover system is very mediocre, with your troops more or less being a gun that you point with your mouse. No dynamic AI, no functional cover shooting. What you have is a game that consists of everything that made the old Rainbow Six games good, but without the same polish that made them fun. Fun diversion for a few hours, but not an 8/10 game.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												Despite being a pretty simple game, Door Kickers is extremely well implemented. The gameplay is smooth, challenging and quite exciting once you get going.The system it uses for upgrades is initially a bit frustrating, requiring a bit of grinding to get enough stars to buy decent equipment but once you get past the first hour of gameplay you'll have most of the end-game items you'd want.For once, the single-mission content is larger than the structured story-line missions to the point where I still haven't managed to finish them all yet. The challenges are a bit on the simplistic side though, I'd like to see a wider variety of bonus challenges (like finishing a map using a specific type of trooper, or without firing a shot) but it's hard to complain with something like 100 levels to master.Definitely worth a purchase, and certainly not unfinished content.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												This game is amazing. It's simple, fun, and easy to understand. Sometimes it gets hard but you can always start over. It's easy as in it throws you in there with no tutorial. LOL GOOD LUCK. It's fun to figure it out. The music is nice, the graphics are amazingly well done, and the animation is on point. Lots of tools for people who are really into strategy and also for people like me, lots of tools you can ignore and get the job done, just a bit less efficiently. (Try losing half your team, oops.) There is a lot of content, many missions and maps to play. Overall this game is well worth the 20 bucks. 8/10 P.S. Avast doesn't want anyone to have fun. There is an issue with this game and compatibility with Avast. I contacted their support and got a brief response. "Hi, It seems AVAST recently started deleting .dll files from our game (even though they're from the known open-source ffmpeg project).You need to pause AVAST, check the game's Steam cache (which will re-download those .dlls) and start the game.If you try running the game with AVAST turned on, it will delete them again, so you need to keep it paused. Unfortunately we don't have a proper solution yet, since it's out of our control, but we're working on it." Damn you Avast and your anti-Doorkickers campaign. I'll get ALL the viruses just to play this game.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Great real-time-with-pause tactical game. You have a squad of swat operatives and take missions with them to kill baddies, rescue hostages, defuse the bomb. Each mission starts with planning mode, where you can choose weapons and gear for your guys and plan movement and actions for completing objectives. Then you hit big red button and watch. You can pause and change plan any time, and even can play in real time, but this is latter is less effective. After mission you earn stars based on performance which you can use to buy upgrades like new weapons and gear.Highly recommended if you like squad-based tactical games.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												This game screams out to fans of Rainbow Six, Splinter Cell, and Metal Gear Solid. The planning options in this game are expansive, and offer players an outstanding amount of ways to complete a mission. There is no "best way" to finish a mission on this game. Assault classes have the armor to withstand bullets head-on, while stealth units are quick enough to clear rooms of enemies without alerting the rest of the area. This game offers so much in the area of replayability, by allowing users to pick different ways to breach, kill, or arrest.I couldn't recommend this game more if I wanted to, it's just an awesome game that definitely needs a buy if you're a fan of any kind of tactical, stealth simulator.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												You have to pick locked doors before kicking them open, i.e. breaking them to pieces. Oh, and get lost with that crappy dubstep soundtrack.Moreover, have fun elaborating plans for a perfect rating - with RNG.I like the logic of the rating system."Oh, the mission took you 30 seconds instead of 20? Bad luck, two stars for you."Next try:"Sir, expendable trooper #2 got badly injured! I don't know if he can ever wield a gun again!""That doesn't matter, you did it in 19 seconds this time! Perfect, three stars for you!"As much as I like challenges, they somehow have to fit into a game. These ones just break the immersion.Furthermore, the game doesn't really explain anything. The tutorial consists of eight video clips and it only covers the gameplay basics which are basically "Spacebar to pause, left click to walk and right click for actions."What about important stuff such as troop management, the ranking system, classes and doctrines? Nah, the complicated stuff you have to figure out yourself.The controls are extremely weird. Without strafing you don't have any chance at all, but sometimes your troopers suddenly stop strafing or they keep strafing when you don't want them to.I guess with a bit of training you get used to them and the game becomes more fun.However, this game threw so much♥♥♥♥♥♥at me in the first hour that I'm not motivated to play any further. I'm just gonna stick to the old Rainbow Six games.

												It's a really good tactics game. Pros - Tons of levels.- Tons of armour.- Tons of weapons.- Tons of utilities and support gear.- Voiced characters.- Alternate appearances for characters.- Workshop support.- Level creator.- XP which leads to upgrades.- Allows mission replays so you can see where you went wrong if you died. Cons- Female officers will speak like men. - Can be very difficult during some missions.- Caps aren't available when customizing callsigns OR names.- Steep price tag if it isn't on offer.- REALLY, REALLY fiddly to give your officers directions. 4/5 times you try to flash bang a door, then go through, the UI will just reset and make you redo your plan again. - Some missions are damn near impossible to complete. Fire gun. Oops they heard, hostage is dead. :^) Fire taser. Oops they heard, hostage is dead. :^) Try and stealth it, shoot the bloke who's closest to the ONLY hostage. Oops you failed it.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												I bought the game on summer sale for a very low price.  Despite this, I'm just under 2 hours and am submitting for refund.At first I thought was a decent pass of time.  But when I got down to actually doing the gold star objectives, I found it incredibly frustrating for a few reasons:-Very often i'll move from point to point with enemies in plain sight and not fire at them-Very often I'll be firing at an enemy but for some reason will disengage and move on to next point regardless of the fact that the not killed enemy is still firing at me-Cannot set rotation points at key spots (like, doors/breaching), which makes the "Live Play" or "Finish in a single set of waypoints" objectives near impossible without just random dumb luck of the positioning of the enemies upon entering a roomThe randomness of behavior of the enemies is actually a fun point and makes the replays decent, but when your own character seems to be doing things completely counter-intuitive to your purpose (kill enemies in plain sight), it's frustrating and even for the price ($3) I find I've gotten bored of the game quickly in 2 attemps to sit and play it now and I'd rather this money go toward another game.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												This game should be awessome. It's both about action and tactics. Unfortunately it's totally overrun with gamebreaking bugs that makes it almost impossible to play. The biggest irony is that it's called "doorkickers" since the doorkicking mechanism contains one of the most severe issues in the entire game: You cannot place yourself in the doorway. By dooing that the dooropening UI hides the UI that allows you to turn in a direction, throw grenades or shoot until there is no threat. Also, backing to the menu does not pause the game, so if there is a tiny flaw in your plan, you want to restart the mission, your entire plan might get eraised. Another thing that drives me crazy is that it impossible to do small changes to your plan. Adjusting it early removes everything after that. So all in all. This game have potential to be extremely good, unfortunately the developers decided to not employ a single tester. It really shows.

												Although I was really looking forward to playing this title, I was very disappointed about the gameplay. The tactical side is unplayable in my opinion. XCOM and Breach & Clear are far better titles in that respect. The turn-based tactival gameplay in those games is just superior. In this game it feels clunky, un-fair and completely random. number of helpful: 3 of 13 people (23%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Amazing game, well worthy of all the praise it gets.The developers are constantly updating, tweaking and adding to the game, and I hear that there is even a multiplayer/co-op mode coming, either for free in a patch, or maybe as paid DLC. Either way, I will take it. These guys deserve every penny.One of the only truly great games to go through early access AND it actually made it to a full release AND it is still supported by the devs now.Very easy to just start playing, it's one of those games that is pretty easy to learn, but difficult to master, especially as the maps go on and get bigger and the enemy get smarter and much much tougher.Workshop support is nice, and there are some truly stunning mods out there, such as the highly rated sound mod that adds almost 100% realistic weapon sounds to every gun in the game, or the many many weapon packs out there that add great weapons from P-90 SMG's to the aliens pulse rifle (ridiculously overpowered, but still good fun).The progression system works nicely, the skill tree is good (although a little small), adding some nice "abilities" to your troopers, such as knowing how to use cover better, better aim with pistols or whatever, using double-tap to make sure enemy are put down quickly. All work nicely to bring your officers in line with the rising difficulty as you get to the tougher maps later on.I seriously can't recommend this game enough. Whether you want to plan as you go, pausing every few seconds, or you want to just go it in real time, dragging the path for your troopers and watching them follow as you go, or you (like me) want to plan everything from the beginning, hit the go button and watch your troopers die quickly :) The game allows any one of these methods, or a mix of all at once, planning a mission from start, then pausing and starting a new plan in the middle (because things start to go sideways), and then just keeping it going in real time, moving your troopers around the map to pick off any stragglers and/or moving any hostages to safety that you couldn't see whilst you were originally planning the assault.The game is great, does exactly what it says on the tin, and does it pretty much perfectly in every way.Worth every penny, and the devs definitely deserve their cash, 100%

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												A solid, fun little game, that suffers from a lack of polish and explanation. Gameplay mechanics are good, and the controls are very simple. They can be picked up very quickly without any kind of tutorial. This is fortunate, since the game does little to explain itself other than a few hints on the controls in the opening missions, and a "How To" that says the same information. Unfortunately, any further explanations of game mechanics, controls, or progression are completely missing. For what is a relatively simple game, this shouldn't have been an issue. However, after having to constantly minimize the game to try and search for answers to simple gameplay mechanics, it become frustrating for something that should otherwise be a quick game to play.Although this game doesn't do anything revolutionary, it is solid. If it had more polish, I would most likely recommend it, but there are too many small problems to justify what should be an easy-to-play game.Thanks for reading.
