								Graphics is good, no bugs that I can see. The only gripe I have is that there is no tutorials beyond the basic 3 slides in the game. I know the devt mentioned that there is no point doing a tutorial at this stage, but it does make the game rather steep to learn.But there is nothing more satisfying than to see your planned mission go off smoothly once you figured out the basics.I do wish that the characters would not moving into the room before the flashbang go off though...And the stopping the hostage execution scenarios are hair-pulling exercises.Better than Frozen Synapse in that the graphics are more engaging, and keeps me interested during the mission, and the pause-anytime-to-plan feature is fantastic.Looking forward to more improvements by the devts!

Posted: December 3, 2015
												So, you're probably sitting here thinking, "Why don't I just get Breach and Clear?". Here are a few reasons why this game is AWESOME! I got Door Kickers in the autumn sales for £2 (I'm a sucker for a bargain) already I have put 4.1 hours into the game just by playing before and after school before dinner. This game is amazing!The sheer brilliance of the customisation means you can have all kinds of you own "classes" on top of the pre-made ones! For example, I created a line up of solely pointmen with silenced pistols and took out the targets with stealth and cunning rather than brute force. It was cool to think I could do all of these new cool tactics!Now, I'm not one to go through a game and get three stars on every level. I just get bored. But for Door Kickers? The fact that you need stars to customise your squad means I want to 100% the game!Also, another great thing is that the most expensive gun/armour/shield isn't nessecarily the best gun/armour/shield! It's all about how you play the game! You can also upgrade the weapon skills of your squad with pistols, long guns and shotguns! This adds a whole other dynamic to the game as you can upgrade your perks or equipment strategically depending on one other!And of course you can name each member squad! You can be as creative as you like! You could call your "crack-shot-with-a-pistol-guy" anything from "Dead-eye" to "Sh**head" This enables you to be slightly attached to your men and be upset if they are killed in the line of fire. And yes, if your men are killed during a campaign, they will not be replaced by new men until you have won/lost the whole campaign! This makes you think about your choices more carefully during an assault on a building.I would highly recommend this game to ANYONE no matter what games they like/play! I recommend picking it up, especially in a sale! Worth the £14.99 its sold for!

Posted: November 26, 2015
												I got this because I love turn-based combat and games like Frozen Synapse bring me great enjoyment. I was not disappointed. The customisation for your squad is pretty good (though I'm unclear what some stats even do), the strategy is fairly deep without being overwhelming, and unlike other games of the genre, it can actually be advantageous to play in "real time" sometimes.There were a couple of minor annoyances for me, like some doorways creating dead angles where the AI can shoot at me but I can't shoot back, even though the two guys are actually touching guns (giggity), using stairways is "fiddly" at best, and some mechanics are frustrating because they're never really explained anywhere (like gun handling when passing corners, body-blocking, etc). I also kinda miss being able to crouch, but that's a minor nitpick.All in all: super fun, very addictive gameplay, would recommend any day of the week.

Posted: March 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is buy far the BEST tactical simulators I have played since 1998 with the release of the first rainbow six. Every aspect of the game is, fluid and smoth. Delivering a marvelous feeling of being right there on the ground when the first door charge goes off, all this despite it being a 2D top down view.When I play it in genarall goes like this.1. Get the lay of the land, (Evaluate points of entry, danger zones, decide distrubation of the squad)2. How to go about it, (Plan paths of moment, cover zones, assert pace requierd to meet the time limits)3. Taking a closer look, (Get eyes inside of target building or area, reasses previous planing on the new info)4. Kicking down the door, (Executing previous planing)Step 1-3 takes between 1-5 minutes unless im picky and decides to plan it all down to the tinyest detail,Step 4 goes in about 10 seconds up to a minute. 5. Improvising in 9/10 times the planing can't cover every base so I generaly have to cut in half way or in the first 3 seconds of the execution and re plan from there whit what I have to work with.It is wonderfull to get a perfect run whitout hicups in the plan but its just as thrilling to be able to salvage a "crashed and burned" plan to still be able to execute the rest.There is a lot of games out there that is worth playing only once, Door kickers is NOT among those titles.You can play it over and over and OVER again, succeding and learning failing and learning. Every time it is a brand new game. If you are a fan of tacsim like me you will get hooked.Score 10/10

Posted: June 25, 2015
												TL;DR6.5/10Don’t go out of your way to recommend it, but if you find the chance, then go for itI first saw this game while searching through the deep dark slums of the farthest-back pages of Steam, and was not immediately encouraged to get Door Kickers. It just looked like a bare-bones, top-down shooter with some mediocre ‘tactical’ elements tossed in. I let it be for a while and then came back to it a couple of months later, then decided “what the heck, I’ll buy it”. I had a total blast for the first week, just playing my way through various missions and unlocking various weapons and armor, but after that, I found myself getting really bored. That is, until I discovered the workshop, and let me tell you; that is what makes this game so great.Gameplay wise, Door Kickers really stands out. None of your soldiers are too overpowered (unless you download god armor from the workshop), so you need to use every last drop of tactical knowledge to keep them alive. Nothing is more frustrating then spending twenty minutes working out a plan and then having all of your troops mowed down by some guy with a machine gun hiding behind a bulletproof couch the instance they kick down the first door. To actually complete a mission you need to buckle down and focus, or you are going to end up with only one guy, cowering in the corner, waiting for someone to come and yell a stereotypical phrase at them then blow your final guy’s head off.All in all, Door Kickers won’t blow you away, but if you like tactical games, then you’ll have some fun with it. If you don’t like those games, then this is probably not the game for you. The graphics aren’t great, but the workshop makes up for that by having new stuff constantly made every day for you to try out. So give it a try if you feel like it, but if you don’t like this type of game, then don’t waste your money on it.6.5/10Don’t go out of your way to recommend it to a friend, but if you find the chance, then go for itBuy it full price if you have the money on hand, but otherwise buy it on sale.~Mfilms2000You can find more of our reviews on our curator page here:http://steamcommunity.com/groups/technosharkreviews

Posted: June 26, 2015
												A game for tacticians who like their challenges realistic and their options almost infinite.  Every door is a problem to be solved - kick it in? place guys on both sides and open it? breach it? toss flashbangs through? try to go in quiet with silencers? jump in with quick reacting pistol wielders? cautiously have the guy with the shield lead the way? jump in with assault rifles and try to overwhelm with sheer force? Switch out the guns to maximize fire rate or accuracy or stopping power? How many people to assign to the door? Do you leave yourself open to being flanked if you stack people on a door? This game is exactly what I want out of tactical strategy.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												You wanna be a hero? Be a hero for a couple seconds and die! You wanna be tactical? Flashbang and then die. You wanna teamwork? Flashbang, have the shields go first, then send in the assault team, unless is CQC, then send in the breachers, maybe a few more flashbangs, bum rush to the hostages if they're about to be killed with the shields in front of you, as the assault/breachers cover your back, and this time have the breachers shoot down the door, as the assault team (or person if you have a 4 guy squad with 2 shields, a assaulter and a breacher) to take down the enemy. Next (again with the shields in front) find a hallway, and put the shields in front of you, having them slowly advance as you check from door to door. Then, if you don't wanna play the full mission, find a hostage and run for your life! (with the shields behind you). You wanna be a traitor? Well...This is how I would best describe this game. As IGN would put it: "Tactical games at its best."As I would put it, "WHO CARES! FLASHBANG THE CRAP OUTTA THE GUYS AND BUMRUSH THEM! Wait... those are the guys reading my review...?"

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Surprising amount of depth for a 2D top-down title. Didn't expect to enjoy this as much as I did but they pretty much did everything right and exceeded all expectations looking at this from previews and gameplay. Entering  each zone is tense and requires a lot of planning and decisions to be made in squad placement, individual loadouts, and directions of approach. Unlocking weapons, skills, and soldier perma-death make for a great progression system. Tacking on the community made maps and mods increases the replayability value on top of the game. Incredibly well-balanced in weapons, armor, and classes with the enemies. It's like Hotline Miami with more tacticality and depth. Would recommend to anyone with a slight passing interest in the game.

Posted: April 27, 2015
Recommended but needs work.Door Kickers is a fun, simple game of strategy and planning. You get the layout of the house you're assaulting, plan each troopers' route, including throwing flashbangs, securing evidence and breaching doors, then hit Action, and watch as your plan unfolds. It is extremely satisfying to watch your plan be executed perfectly.There are a few things that need to be worked out, however. Planning a trooper's movement requires the use of waypoints, where you order the trooper to look a certain direction, open a door, or use one of their gadgets. Once you've placed a waypoint and moved on to the next one, you are limited in your editing abilities. You can either delete the waypoint or change the action, but you cannot move the waypoint. Also, if you delete one waypoint, it will delete all proceeding waypoints as well. So if you make a mistake early on, your whole route has to be redone. This makes editing the route very difficult and time consuming. Currently, you cannot export a replay on Mac.

												Excellent, excellent game- the kind of game where you have been playing it and look at the clock and see "Oh, it's bedtime... I will just play one more scenario"- and then three hours later you are like "OMG I gotta work tomorrow!"The music fits perfectly and is awesome (I could just let it play in the background all day), scenarios are quick and replayable.  I have only just begun the content and I feel like I can't get enough of it!  The graphics style and point of view is refreshing.If you don't like a lot of blood I guess that might be a negative point, but I highly recommend this game if you like planning and strategy type games with customization options for your squad members, skill trees, equipment changes... none of these look too overblown but there is just a light enough touch of them to keep it interesting.Waited for this to be on sale but in retrospect, would have paid full price.  Great game so far

Posted: February 19, 2015
												Door kickers is a fantastic top down shooter, but not quite like every other one.What sets door kickers apart is its almost 'blueprint' type of plan and play. The base of the game is you have a squad of customizable soldiers that you must guide through a small area in a strategic way while taking as few casualties as possible and comleting the objective. The objectives range from anything from saving hostages, to disarming bombs, to simply killing every enemy and more.How to command each soldier is relatively simple, click and drag a path for them to follow. If you want to get fancy you can even right click and drag an arrow to where you want them to look at different points on the path making for effective straffing manuvers. You must plan your path carefully because you are not given the location of your enemies and therefore it pays to be strategic. If you do futz it up, there is a pause button that you can activate anytime durring the mission and replan your squads next move.Obtaining new equipment for your soldiers is like other games with a progression system. as you progress you get points to spend on new equipment such as heavier bullet-proof vests, new weapons, riot shields, etc. Although the customization may make the game seem unfair and favor you, it counters that by giving you a ton of enemies or the satisfaction of knowing that you planned just right. For example, if there's a room of 10 enemy soldiers right in front of you and you only have 4 guys, you're not going to send them all in with ligh armour and tiny pistols. What you can do is customize your squad to have heavy armour, have 2 swap out their primary weapons for riot shields, and the others to carry assault riffles and stack up on each other providing heavy fire and protection in the trade off for mobility and a quick trigger finger. It's these trade offs that make the difference in how you plan and make the strategic aspect of the game very inportant.There is also a skill tree menu for your soldiers. Along with unlocking new equipment you can 'train' your team to give them boosts such as aiming faster, more accurately, following up with a second shot to make sure the enemy is dead, hold their fire for those who like to be stealthy, and so on and so forth.The game also has a number of little things it will throw in from time to time to help it feel a little more 'real'. This includes an uncertain amount of baddies on many levels, 'cause who knows if they called for back up of not? You occasionally get a sniper friend to help you because back up never hurt you either (in fact, it seems a little overpowered, but I'm not complaining). Your soldiers CAN die! After all those missions you go through together, all the promotions they've earned, all the gear you've given them, and they just one day *pew pew* and you just have to sit there for a minute wondering why you were so foolish and sent your commerade out into a blaze of fire and know you lost the best soldier on your team *sniffle sniffle*. (Quietly whispers) "He was so young..." Ok, now back to what I was saying. You must also tell your crew to reload because contrary to many games, you don't just majically know when to reload, you first have to walk into enemy fire, pull the trigger, realize you're out of ammo, and get shot in the midst of reloading because you forgot to tell your poor soldier to reload. This isn't to forget that there is a cover system in the game. If you can pull out and behind a barrel to give yourself adequate cover for a moment, it could really save you in a pinch, and if you're like me, give an oppertunity to reload. Before I get too far off topic I should mention that you do gain new soldiers back ofter a few missions, they may grow on trees in this game, but that doesn't mean it's an instant replacement.Door Kickers also assists you by adding stealth mechanics also (but let's be honest, guns aren't the quietest things).The line of sight really is your best friend in this game because as long as you can intrude it by hiding behind a door or something (Are you happy now? I mentioned doors just like you were waiting for), you can use this to help get into a good spot to take down the enemy from all sides, or over all to your advantage depending on the plan. In adition to the line of sight, you should also try to be relatively quiet unless you bring out the big guns. This is thanks to a small sound system they threw in so you can't simply blow up doors and have ever enemy go "Hey, you hear something?" and the other guy say "Nah, it's probably just the wind" *cough* skyrim *cough*.Now although It's easy to slip up (like me) and forget to reload (like me) and get your people killed (like me), your not completely hopeless. The fix to being an idiot (guess like who? yup, like me) is to add a somewhat self sufficent AI, so if your soldier runs into a tough spot or gets shot by someone out of their line of sight, they can do things like turn to them and shoot them, or if they're heavily armoured and can take a few hits to buy some time before dying and their clip ran out, they will try to reload it. Although it may not seem like it, this small bit of AI that can help take care of little things can really help win a mission.Now, finally you say, "Okay, I beat the game, what now?" Well, the good people that made this game thought of that and have little side objectives such as complete a level without causualties ot in a certain time frame or something to help add some play time. When you finish with that there's even more. They even threw in a random map generator to add even more hours of play. You just have to put in what you want, things such as: nuber of enemies, map size, if you want fog of war, etc. and out pops a map for you. Pretty nice, huh?Given that the game is called Door Kickers, you may be reading this and say "Hey, what's with the lack of busting down doors?" and so this goes out to you. You can:-pick the lock-use a crowbar-C4-Blast if open with a shot gun-open it and chuck a grenade through-make a sound to lure the baddies and have them open it for you-whatever else you can think of doing, you got options, be creative and knock yourself out.Rating: 9/10Very solid experience in my time, try not to run directly into a house full of enemies and you should be pretty set. The progression system isn't a favorite of mine and the line of sight can be weird sometimes, but hey, it's not half bad.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Door Kickers is an amazing game which is definetely worth the price, but does have a few bugs, which is expected.First of all, the gameplay in general, and the way you control the S.W.A.T. team is very well done in my opinion. It's fairly simple to map out plans and create strategies for completing missions, while also allowing a variety of different actions. The weapon variety is plentiful, but there should be more interesting gadgets to use. There are lots of levels, and different campaigns to go through which should keep you busy for a while. New ones are being made all the time too. Also, the animations look fluid.DESPITE THIS there are some ♥♥♥♥ing annoying things that NEED to be fixed.One thing I hate is that your men can be real dumbasses sometimes. Often, if there is an enemy behind two guys, and he kills one of them, the other guy, whose buddy JUST DIED right next to him, won't even turn around to engage the enemy, even if that enemy doesn't move or even just stays and reloads! You have to manually turn him around, which can get very annoying and often results in another dead trooper. This doesn't always happen, but it needs to be fixed. Another small thing is that the female SWAT members have male voices.Overall, I recommend the game. Soon this will be fixed and the game will be perfect

Posted: January 1, 2016
												A tactical game where you take control of a swat team that you can customize with dozens of guns and items. As far as guns go, there are pretty much 4 types, and there's no real incentive to use anything other than the best gun of each type: either the best SMG for close quarters, the best shotgun, the best rifle, or the best silenced weapon. Pistols behave similarly. However, the core strategy experience is deep and addicting. The tutorial is really insufficient to acquaint you with new features of the game, as I was still discovering "advanced" controls after 10+ hours.That said, holy fudge, this game is tons of fun. As you start to master the controls, the rush and satisfaction of breaching a door, placing a few well placed bullets into the generic "terrorists", and saving the hostages, you'll forget all about any problems. Plus, the game itself comes with a robust level editor, and custom content is worth the price of admission on its own. The game comes (right now) with 120+ individual missions and 6 campaigns. It's a lot of content, and with about 20 hours logged I'm done with the 4 shortest campaigns, and a mere <30 missions. I've unlocked everything except the clearly worse guns, but I'm still playing like there's more to unlock- the game is just that fun.If you like strategy games or are looking for a unique SWAT type sim, listen to the hype- this game is GREAT.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												Perfect bite-sized strategy with all the 'one shot gravitas' and faux bravado a good round of Rogue Spear would muster. Part puzzle part strategy with some pseudo RPG elements. Tons of stock levels, a random mission generator, and a strong mission editor mean lots of replay value even if you never touch the effortlessly integrated Steam Workshop for mods or community levels.It was an impulse buy based on looks and concept, and surprised me in a good way. If it looks even remotely appealing to you, get it!

Posted: December 30, 2014
												I played this game and enjoyed it.If you liked the old SWAT tactical shooter, here's something you will enjoy. The good thing about this is that there's actual planning invovled - ypou don't just send your men in guns blazing, cause that way most or all of them will go back in bodybags. Here you have to plan ahead and every room you clear matters. One unexpected event will often demand of you to re-think your strategy. This is NOT a game wher eyou plan, then hit "execute" and forget about the whole thing. Far from what it may seem from screenshots or short videos, this is a thinking man's game.Another good part of it is that there's more replayability than meets the eye. The same scenario will vary from one playthrough to the next. You may encounter different number of foes, in diffrent places, with different behaviour, armament and patrol patterns than you seen in your last playthrough of a given scenario. There are a lot of scenarios on tp of it all.There is also an RPG-style mechanic - your SWAT agents will rise in skill after participating in missions, you will also get access to more armor types, weapon and doctrines as you complete more missions. Doctrines act much as passive bonuses in mmorpgs. This works pretty well, although it is primarily a tactical game and the rpg elements are not as deep as in complex mmos.Only two downsides I can think of are two elements from the SWAT games taht I miss here - there's no tear gas and there's little in the way of opponent morale - 99% of foes will fight to the death and not surrender.

Posted: April 21, 2015
												Every now and then, a game comes along and fills a gap in the market that I didn't really know needed to be filled - Door Kickers is one such game. Inspired in no small part by the planning phases of late 1990s Tom Clancy games, Door Kickers is a thought provoking adrenaline rush of anti-terrorism action-puzzles. There's two ways you can play Door Kickers. You can either take advantage of the ability to pause & issue commands in real time, edging your way through a level one command at a time, carefully assessing your options before pushing onwards... Then there's the right way - You plan everything from the get go. One continuous stream of commands that'll see your trooper(s) go from room to room, checking their corners and, hopefully, never leaving themselves open to an ambush. The sense of accomplishment from laying down a perfect plan that requires no tweaking after the mission starts is pretty special, and adds so much challenge to the game that you'll be entertained for hours and hours.Levels vary wildly from simple elimination jobs, to bomb defusal, hostage rescue, and evidence gathering. No two levels are the same, and thanks to the numerous ways to approach each, there's potentially no limit to replayability. Replayability is also helped by a multi-tier challenge system & a pretty strong community modding scene. The in-game custom level generator makes designing & sharing levels with others really simple, and it's fun to see how challenging a level can actually be when designed by someone other than a sensible developer.Character variety is a-plenty as the game has a generous amount of specialized classes & customization, along with veterancy rewards and dedicated fighting styles. Completing campaign levels in the best possible way will require a well rounded squad of multiple talents, but be warned - Death is permanent in campaign modes, and it's possible to lose a talented officer in just one poor move.It's not all great, though. Music & voice acting is less than mediocre, while the graphics are pretty much just fit for purpose. There could also be very slight improvements to mission planning, but the developers have proven their intent to better the game, and it's by no means bad right now - It just could be a little better, that's all.Overall, Door Kickers is a resounding recommendation. A collection of standalone tactical puzzles, campaigns & UGC, all wrapped in an attractive enough package with amazing character customization & challenges galore. If you're in any way  intrigued, then jump in without hesitation.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												TL;DR6.5/10Don’t go out of your way to recommend it, but if you find the chance, then go for itI first saw this game while searching through the deep dark slums of the farthest-back pages of Steam, and was not immediately encouraged to get Door Kickers. It just looked like a bare-bones, top-down shooter with some mediocre ‘tactical’ elements tossed in. I let it be for a while and then came back to it a couple of months later, then decided “what the heck, I’ll buy it”. I had a total blast for the first week, just playing my way through various missions and unlocking various weapons and armor, but after that, I found myself getting really bored. That is, until I discovered the workshop, and let me tell you; that is what makes this game so great.Gameplay wise, Door Kickers really stands out. None of your soldiers are too overpowered (unless you download god armor from the workshop), so you need to use every last drop of tactical knowledge to keep them alive. Nothing is more frustrating then spending twenty minutes working out a plan and then having all of your troops mowed down by some guy with a machine gun hiding behind a bulletproof couch the instance they kick down the first door. To actually complete a mission you need to buckle down and focus, or you are going to end up with only one guy, cowering in the corner, waiting for someone to come and yell a stereotypical phrase at them then blow your final guy’s head off.All in all, Door Kickers won’t blow you away, but if you like tactical games, then you’ll have some fun with it. If you don’t like those games, then this is probably not the game for you. The graphics aren’t great, but the workshop makes up for that by having new stuff constantly made every day for you to try out. So give it a try if you feel like it, but if you don’t like this type of game, then don’t waste your money on it.6.5/10Don’t go out of your way to recommend it to a friend, but if you find the chance, then go for itBuy it full price if you have the money on hand, but otherwise buy it on sale.~Mfilms2000You can find more of our reviews on our curator page here:http://steamcommunity.com/groups/technosharkreviews

Posted: April 23, 2015
												This game really makes you think before you send your teams in. Best blend of tactics and strategy I've ever played in a game. Every mission is different and really makes you put thought into it. So many weapons, armors, and secondaries. You can breach a door with a shotgun and send a squad in with assault rifles with a sniper set outside a window to cover them going in. My favorite part of the game is how you can divvy up your movements into sequences. For instance, once you plan your teams' routes, you can divide their movements to into sections. So. you can have one team sneak in and clear an area silently and cut off an escape route and begin phase "A" where another team will blow their door open for a loud entrance and move in. You can then set phases B thru D for movement after things are clear, certain enemies have been eliminated, etc. It's probably the most satisfying when you're preplanned movements finish a mission without pausing it to readjust.I would suggest maybe a headswivel option for when one of your routes end. This would enable one or more units to watch all around them so they don't get snuck up on.I would also suggest a little more user-friendly map creation.Other than that, this is a must-buy game for those interested in a truly amazing tactical/strategic SWAT game.

												What a delightful find. The game is focussed around programming your SWAT team to quickly navigate a variety of environments and compelte set missions. Posted: February 24, 2015
												One of the best tactical games I have ever played. For an overhead 'god' sort of game, this is the best one out there. Combined with levelling up, customising andcontrolling your troopers, the pause/unpause, GO codes and dynamic breaching methods and manouvers this is definently a game worth investing in. Recent updates include lots more challenging maps and campaigns that will keep you hooked for ages. There isn't the same way to complete a mission twice, every time you start a mission, the enemy, hostages and possibly even the bomb change positions, allowing for hours of ever changing fun. Posted: October 27, 2014
												I'm sure that this is a good game, but for a casual scumbag like me (I'll insult myself to save you guys the trouble. You're welcome.), it's not ideal. If you're into strategy games, look no further. If not, don't bother. On to the review.From what I've seen so far (And that says a lot, with less than 30 minutes of gameplay), is that the strategic element is definitely there, and it's well executed. As long as you're not too impatient, you won't have any problems with it. I like that this is the kind of strategy game where you REALLY have to calculate your moves in order to win, as opposed to some where it's favorable but not quite necessary. The art style is pretty appealing to the eye, as it's simple, yet not cartoon-like. I haven't encountered any bugs yet (Perhaps because of the low play time.), so it gets a plus for that. The customization goes around choosing your characters' equipment based on a class system and changing their names, perhaps more, which is quite perfect. The maps are also quite nice, from what I've seen.Did I enjoy the game? No, but that does not mean I think it's bad. Just not my type of game.Do I recomend it? Yes and no, depending on if you like strategy games or not. Though, I know that Door Kickers is a good game for what it is, so I'm giving it a positive review.

Posted: October 28, 2014
												An absolutely outstanding experience, I've really never played a game like it before.Door Kickers is a top down, Real time strategy game unlike any other i have played before. you control a swat team of various size depending on the mission you pick, you can either chose single missions or play a campaign mode which is a set of specific missions with varying objectives that span all game types. Drug Busts, Hostage Rescue, Elimination, arrest warrant. and so on.You have two ways you can do this, create a plan in the planning phase or just go all out and control the team members in real time (I do not recomend this) The planning is the star of this game, set each individual team members path of movement and direction they are facing, set certain way points such as getting them to hold a certain position until all hostiles in his field of view are dead or getting them to hold a certain position until you give them the go ahead to continue n their pre-planned path.How well this plan is executed however is dependant on the equipment and upgrades you have unlocked. After each mission you are awarded EXP, how much EXP you are awarded is dependant on how many stars you were rated and how many challenges you completed within the mission.EXP goes toward levels which span your entire team, each time you level up you ear stars and points, the stars can be spent on new and better gear where as the points are spent in the skill tree to improve your team members proficiency with certain weapons.the game has classes, at first you just have the "point Man" class but you soon start to unlock the others. Assaulter, Shield, Breacher and Stealth. each one unlocking at a specific milestone. when you first start out you'll most likely spend a lot of time replaying old missions to get used to the mechanics but it's when you've unlocked every class that the game really picks up.Customizing your team per mission with the classes certain missions may need.The game comes with a mission creator though the UI in that map creator isn't very helpful, in fact it feels like more of a hinderence, text of items over lap each other to the point where you can't read them and the creator also offers you no help, no explanation on how to use the funtion.it is a very in depth mission creator when you look at everything you are able to place and control but as i said, it offers you no explanation on how to use these things.For example i clicked on the "Walls" tool, expecting myself to be able to place walls only for the walls not showing up at all in the test run of the map and since the creator offers you no help, i had no idea why this wasn't happening.All in all i'd give this ame a 7/10 and that 7 comes from the main game alone, the map creator gets a 0 from me purely because it offers you no help what so ever, like it expects you to know how to use everything without ever having used it before.

												Pros:+ Realistic take on Police CQB action.+ Easy to learn, hard to master.+ Wide selection of gears.+ Simple, yet beautiful and effective 2-D graphics.+ Lots of single missions and some interesting campaigns.+ Ability to record and replay a mission from start to end, even converting it to videos.Cons:- 2-D representation of the action may not appeal to all.- Only a handful of campaigns.- Conversion of replays to video not available for the Mac OS X platform.Bottomline:A perfect game for those of us growing up with the original Rainbow Six and SWAT 3 games, who are wishing for a realistic CQB action.

												Rewardingly and frustratingly difficult. I found myself striving to get five stars on absolutely every mission, going every angle, weapon, and piece of gear to get the perfect combination. Careful planning is generously encouraged since every time I didn't carefully plan ( and a lot of times when I did ) the game would brutally punish and have my whole squad wiped out by one guy in one corner I didn't think I'd need to sweep on entry. With 33 hrs in as of writing this, I still haven't gotten through all the campaign levels, which are unique in approach and scale compared to the shorter missions menu. Posted: June 16, 2015
												To start this off i dont write many reviews so I hope its ok and ill keep it short and sweet.OMFG Door Kickers is so amazing I just had to review it. So I like strategy games and have only played a few really decent ones (my opinion) Xcom, JA2 and this weird old school flash game called Field Commando or something, Field commando was a 'crappy lil game' that looked like it took 2 seconds to make but the idea of controlling (Very restricted) a military squad was awesome. Door Kickers is what i dreamt Field  Commando would have been if they worked harder. IT IS AMAZING.Pros - Great soundtrack, Keeps up the tension/atmosphere.        - Massive range of difficulty.        - Different types of missions (not just take out the enemy but arresting people and rescuing hostages)        - Graphics are better then Field Commando (you're not a circle haha)        - (To me) Highly replayable, yes I might not sit here for hours playing it but I will deffinatley play it  again and again  when im bored or have time to kill.        - Reasonably priced (although i got 75% off in steam sales paid like 5 bucks US)         - Unlock weapons and armour.        - You can have a squad of like 8 men all taking out different targets at the same time. Feels good to wipe out like 20  enemies in like 2 seconds.Cons - Not many         - Graphics could still be better.         - It will frustrate the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you.         - Times dissappears when you have 'just one more crack at the mission'         - Few glitches and my guys died a few times getting shot from someone who they couldnt shoot(i was hiding and they could see and arm, enemies could shoot me but my guy just took it and died.BoldyB - Give it a go. Better value for money then WarZ.....oh wait Infestation surviv......oh you lost interest :(

												Highly recommended for all fans of tactical games. It's already a very addictive and fun game and it's just alpha! It's quite similar to Frozen Synapse in some ways, but it's pausable real time(you will pause quite a bit) instead of being turn based. This kind of a plan & pause system is perfect for the game. You have a wide selection of weapons to choose from and there will be squad progression with promotions, etc. It's great now and it will be even better when all the features are implemented.----------------------------Post release UPDATE: The game is now better than ever. Many things are improved and implemented, including individual trooper level progression, campaign and iron man mode(missions can't be restarted, but you get double EXP), etc. The game is even better with the Rainbow Six character and sound mods (available on Steam Workshop!)

Posted: February 27, 2015
												A brilliant and frustratingly hard tactical squad-based game. For the most part the physics, AI and mechanics are fluid and well done, with a few annoying moments from your squad who react unpredictably. I guess, to a degre, this adds realism perhaps. I love tactical and strategy games and I find this hugely fun, with loads of missions, custom maps, squad upgrades and challenges. It has a lot of replay value for me, though I can see some people feeling otherwise. It is definitely still worth the money however. My only gripe is that some of the classes have to be unlocked by levelling your squad and this feels a bit like a mechanic from a cheap or free mobile phone game, and feels really irritating at times when you are faced with a scenario and you long for one of the locked classes. Minor issue, however. If you play it lots and do well you quickly unlock all the classes.

Posted: December 26, 2014
												This is awesome. There's almost like three games in one here, the first type where you just control the game as normal and try to win the mission, the second type where you do it with one guy, and the third type where you do it as a "one plan only" style. Each type is interesting enough to stand out from the other, and it also has an interesting campaign mode series. There are a few minor control quirks but once you get used to the system you can do pretty powerful plans. There's pretty much no storyline to speak of though, which is something that could be worked on.

Posted: October 27, 2014
												Door Kickers: 6/10Door Kickers is an interesting concept -- one that's been done before, but not as often as people hope. The cult classic Rainbow Six 3: Raven Shield being the quintessential example of this type of game, Door Kickers takes a similar approach in trying to create an atmosphere of tactical tension, albeit with a bit of levity involved in the presentation. In recent years, we've also seen the well-made Breach & Clear released, which was an underappreciated game that took the Rainbow Six formula, made it purely top-down, and focused the action in on three-second pseudo-realtime moments.So, there is quite an audience for this type of game built in already -- many people love this type of tactical action for two reasons; as games, they provide a thrill unlike any other. This isn't Call of Duty, where rasberry jam will be smeared all over your character's face if you improperly clear a room: if you fail to properly check your corners, your character will die, and this creates a sheer tension towards entering and moving through buildings in any properly executed Tactical game. A second reason is more of a gritty tactical feel -- it's not really the thrill of playing a game, but the thrill of using real tactics, real equipment, and truly mastering these raids until you can defeat most levels on the first try. Rainbow Six leaned towards the latter. Breach & Clear aimed towards the former. Door Kickers gets stuck somewhere in the middle.As a game, Door Kickers has a very 'hotshot' atmosphere. The achievements, menu tips, and even the interface all make it out as a Call of Duty-esque experience that challenges you to play. The gameplay can either be taken very tactically and slowly,  or in a more brash realtime mode where squaddies will just follow your mouse as long as you hold and drag them around. Neither of these modes works perfectly. For example; as a game, the gameplay quickly falls apart when you realize just how rote and routine winning each level becomes. Going back to Breach & Clear, each level was interesting enough, but sweeping rooms was really only half the battle. Using your items and abilities intelligently was really what carried you forwards. In Door Kickers, using items effectively is useful, but nonessential. Setting up intelligent fire zones and sweeping a room carefully will let you beat every single level in the game with the basic Assault class.And speaking more towards classes, the RPG elements of Door Kickers are not as deep as those presented in other games. If you're going to put a character progression system into a game, it has to feel like your characters are progressing. Let me explain: XCom: Enemy Unknown is a perfect example. In the earliest parts of the game, your recruits are pathetic. They can't shoot, they can't hit anything, and they have no useful abilities. They'll get slaughtered. However, as you play more and more, you really begin to bond with them; you create little vignettes in your head of everything they've done as soldiers, and you see them come to life with powerful abilities and interesting weapons. You thrill at their victories, and gasp at their failures. In Breach & Clear, this also happens; you create a squad of soldiers and deploy them for the entire game, slowly levelling them to the point of creating a cohesive crack team of unique and varied soldiers. Door Kickers really just expediates this process to the point where it's completely pointless. I had a maximum-level squad within the first five hours of gameplay, and none of my squad members really stood out. The small stat increases they receive are fairly pointless, and it's really their loadout that affects things more than their actual skill. Furthermore, you can just swap all of them between classes at will, so there's no real reason to specialize anyone. You gain a lot of tactical freedom, but lose all of the characters and personality that could've been developed here.So, Door Kickers isn't really a perfect game -- it's not too challenging, nor is it really relatable. So, is it, at least, tactical? To a degree, I would say it is, but in a very frustrating way. As aforementioned, it works as a room clearing simulator. Entering a room is interesting and fun, and you begin to pick up some actual tactical acumen as you play through the game. But then, you begin to suddenly realize what a dearth of options there really are in the game. You, of course, have five classes. Pointman - which becomes entirely useless about twenty minutes into the game, Assault - Which is the only class you really need to win every map, Breacher - Which is a nice class to have, but becomes a short-ranged assault about three hours into the game, Shield - Which is slow moving, doesn't do much damage, and is incredibly situational, and finally Stealth - Which is very similar to Assault, but completely superfluous and is preferable in only a few tiny instances.Now, the thing you may have noticed is that all of these classes seem to just bleed into the Assault class towards the end; the shield is, perhaps, the only one that remains entirely unique, and it's so rarely useable that it becomes like a health potion in a roleplaying game. You look at it, sigh, and say to yourself, "Maybe next time. I should save it." Furthermore, the inventories on all of the classes are almost entirely identical. Taking a game like Rainbow Six into account, you could arm any individual soldier with eight categories of weapons, each of which had twenty weapons, and several ammunition subtypes -- and that's not even getting into the modification system. In this game, each class has about 16 weapons available, and no modification system to speak of. As far as items go, the game is at a loss as well; this is a game about breaching and clearing rooms, so where the hell are the doorjams? Where are the fragmentation grenades? Where are the smoke grenades? Heartbeat sensors? Instead, you have some very basic options in the form of:Flashbangs - The most useful item in the game.Stingers - Very situational, not recommended.Breaching Charges - Situational, but you need something to pad your inventory.Lockpicks - Situational.Hammer - SituationalSnakecam - Mandatory.And a few others. Out of all of these, the three most useful ones are automatically equipped on the characters at the start of the game, making it pretty basic to load your troops out.So, then you get into the tactical meat of the game, and you become inundanted in a complete nightmare of artificial stupidity. The game makes a point to challenge you to use one plan to clear the entire building from the start of the match -- this is standard. Rainbow Six 1-3 were based on this concept of planning, and the planning room in this game is a pretty close recreation of what those games had. The only issue comes with the AI; both friendly and hostile. Your own troops are, for the most part, somewhat intelligent, but have moments of immense stupidity that make you want to throw your keyboard across the room. Your men start approaching a door, 2x2 cover formation. The door opens -- they quickly blow away the mook with an AK on the other side, and..They completely freeze in place. Why? Because I had them set to lockpick that door that he just blew open. The soldiers can't understand that the door isn't there, so they just stand and patiently wait. This is all well and fine when you have four guys stacked up, but when one soldier tries to pick the lock and a guy with a pistol opens the door, that soldier will just freeze, completely nonresponsive for minutes on end as the enemy tries to blow through his heavy body armor with the equivalent of an airsoft gun. I'd type more, but I have to cut this short; the game is buggy, unfair, and pretty shallow, but it's the closest a game has gotten to the old Rainbow Six feel. If you like those games, get it. You won't regret it.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												So, you're probably sitting here thinking, "Why don't I just get Breach and Clear?". Here are a few reasons why this game is AWESOME! I got Door Kickers in the autumn sales for £2 (I'm a sucker for a bargain) already I have put 4.1 hours into the game just by playing before and after school before dinner. This game is amazing!The sheer brilliance of the customisation means you can have all kinds of you own "classes" on top of the pre-made ones! For example, I created a line up of solely pointmen with silenced pistols and took out the targets with stealth and cunning rather than brute force. It was cool to think I could do all of these new cool tactics!Now, I'm not one to go through a game and get three stars on every level. I just get bored. But for Door Kickers? The fact that you need stars to customise your squad means I want to 100% the game!Also, another great thing is that the most expensive gun/armour/shield isn't nessecarily the best gun/armour/shield! It's all about how you play the game! You can also upgrade the weapon skills of your squad with pistols, long guns and shotguns! This adds a whole other dynamic to the game as you can upgrade your perks or equipment strategically depending on one other!And of course you can name each member squad! You can be as creative as you like! You could call your "crack-shot-with-a-pistol-guy" anything from "Dead-eye" to "Sh**head" This enables you to be slightly attached to your men and be upset if they are killed in the line of fire. And yes, if your men are killed during a campaign, they will not be replaced by new men until you have won/lost the whole campaign! This makes you think about your choices more carefully during an assault on a building.I would highly recommend this game to ANYONE no matter what games they like/play! I recommend picking it up, especially in a sale! Worth the £14.99 its sold for!

Posted: December 27, 2014
												This game is fresh to me. I haven't played anything quite like it. You can't do campaign mode right away, you have to play a few single missions and level up first. This is basically to get you warmed up for the campaign missions because campaign there is perma death. Your task force officers rank up too, and your level points get you better gear. Basically a mission operates in 3 phases1. Deploy mode. Select your officers and deploy them onto the mission site in a selected area. 2. Planning mode. This is where you trace out the movement and actions of each officer. There are a variaty of options on how to do this depending on rank and equipment. 3. Execution mode. This is when the mission starts and your men begin to perform your plan, you can go back to planning mode at anytime and redo the planor if you're feeling brave you can do the planning and execution simultaniously. At the end of your mission you are graded by speed, deaths, and overall performance. 3 star ranking gets you more XP which can be used for more lethal officers and tactics. Planning mode gets complcated quick, you can customize it to do so many things like switch weapons, look in certain directions, don't move again until enemies cleared, and there are even wait for order Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, or Delta so a certain officer will wait until you click the order and then continue as plan. This game is quick paced, and a great time killer. I think I will enjoy it for a long time, classic replay value. Overall I give it 8 out of 10 ♥♥♥♥ Pandas

Posted: January 3, 2015
												Wow, been looking for a game like this for a long time. Door Kickers harks back to the classic days of late 90s PC gaming, specifically games like Rainbow 6 & SWAT - "tooling-up" a hit team with your own unique load out of weaponry, formulating a plan to take down the bad guys, and executing that plan in syncronicty with your various teams. I love devising new strategies for maps, and the ability to change you orders rapidly and easily on the fly is what makes the game special. There's challenges and a tech tree to climb to keep things interesting and satisfy different playing styles.Relatively simple, but utterly addictive and thoroughly satisfying. If you like a mix of planning, strategy and action - this game is for you!

Posted: January 7, 2015
												Door Kickers is the best top down tactical simulator in the world in my opinion, and I have played a lot of top down simulators. Door Kickers has very rich components, from its music to its tactics. The music is extremely atmospheric, making it feel like Payday 2, except you're the tactical advisor. The tactics are extremely rich, giving you so much space to establish the best path and tactic to get the mission done. And you have a lot of customization for the SWAT Officers on your team, whether he/she would be a pointman or breacher, wielding a shotgun or rifle.The client is also very smooth and slick, allowing for uninterrupted and smooth gameplay. And with randomly generated doors to kickdown, the game is endless and can be educational. Making sure your officers never forget to check their corners and always stop before entering a room when your fellow officer hasn't caught up with you. This is a very realistic tactical simulator and is an essential game to stratagy lovers.

Posted: June 24, 2016
												I feel that this is a very good game. I like the game concept and pacing of the missions. The missions are interesting but short enough. The game mechanics are not difficult to learn, but level design and the equipment customization ability allows one to try multiple approaches to complete a mission. With good planning of equipment and paths, the team can complete the actual mission in very short time. There are some things that can be improved. For example, the UI makes it difficult to pick individual team members when they stand very closely together. Path creation UI can also be improved, e.g. to allow easy modification of an early segment without having to redo the rest of the path. The variety of weapons also don't seem to matter so much -- for example, many of rifle choices for assaulter class don't seem to offer distinct advantage compared to e.g. P90 or SAR-18 option. Lastly, it's better if some action options are added, e.g. ability for a team member to look around and clear the room before moving. At the moment, there's only option to look at one direction, confirm that it's clear, move slightly, look at another direction, confirm that it's clear, and so on. Another ability that will come in handy is the ability to synchronize team member to only move after a flashbang (without using go codes), the ability to specify alternate action (e.g. when the door that is supposed to be breached is already opened by someone else), and ability to combine actions on one item during planning (e.g. unlock the door, then throw a flashbang through it).Having said that, those issues are minor, and I still highly recommend this game.

Posted: September 27, 2016
												This game knows what it is and what it aims to be and accomplishes that very well.  I got this in a bundle that was very cheap, and it blew me away.  At it's full retail price, you'd probably want to look into some gameplay videos first to make sure it's something that you'd enjoy.  The big factor being that it focuses much more on strategy and team prep than rich 3d graphics and hero-esque characters.It can be brutal, but encourages creative thinking and being smart about your choices.  Losing a squad mate has weight here, and helps to push you to be careful with your actions, which adds a big immersive element.  Squad progression is done nicely, which makes the game's overall progression feel more balanced, and adds depth to an already fun set of mechanics.If this is on sale or in a bundle, it's an absolute no brainer, if only to test your strategic mettle.  If you enjoy strategy above all else in your games, even if you aren't a fan of military themes/shooters, this is still a great value.

Posted: April 1
												For the complete review: https://retrospectgamer.wordpress.com/2017/03/14/door-kickers-review/You’re given an entire SWAT team to manage, their basic equipment to upgrade, and bunch of missions to complete. The missions themselves are quite interesting, with difficult situations like hostage rescue arising from time to time.The artwork is good, and the special effects are alright. And so is the soundtrack. Nothing spectacular.The controls are not the best, as drawing lines around and on top of existing ones can get quite glitchy.Everything said, this game is definitely different from anything I've played so far.I recommend this game for anyone looking for a new experience in the ‘tactical’ department.

Posted: September 16, 2016
												Decent game but has many shortcommings. Wait for sale and get it dirt cheap.Level design spans from good to clowncars of baddies - even in home invasion mission there are 1-3 people in every single room of 3 story apartment and you get 4 troppers to clear that! upgrade progression makes no sense in this type of game and is very limiting - it is a big hump at the start of the game, ranking missions based on complete time makes no sense in this type of game (and you need lotsa stars to unlock Stealth class, takes forever!), givig you worthless recruits makes no sense. Too many weapons which do not differ much if at all cluttering the list.The troops will show too much initiative and shoot the first guy they see even if you order them to hook around the doorway and check the far corner, but at the same time they need to be instructed to sidestep around every corner.RNG aspects: your troops will occasionally fail to fire first when a tango shows up even if they are aimed exactly at the corner and static. No ammount of foresight can prevent this on occasions.Did I mention star system? Cannot 3 star all missions as you go along, most of them need equipment and classes you will unlock later, so you might need 1 star many to them go back and try to redo them.I spent hours few years bacl playing Rouge Spear in spectator mode and I expected this to be better.

If you want a tactical swat game this is pretty good.I was excited to play it after a foray into Breach and Clear, which I thought was very good. This game is better in that the pacing is a little faster.  But everything else, IMO, is worse than what you will get with Breach and Clear.  The graphics here aren't great, which is a given since it's a tablet game.  The sound isn't great either; and the animations are clumsy at best.  The controls also feel a little imprescise, having my officer face the wrong way is common.Still, it's not a bad game, and I think most people will have fun.

The game mechanics are not difficult to learn, but level design and the equipment customization ability allows one to try multiple approaches to complete a mission. With good planning of equipment and paths, the team can complete the actual mission in very short time. There are some things that can be improved. For example, the UI makes it difficult to pick individual team members when they stand very closely together. Path creation UI can also be improved, e.g. to allow easy modification of an early segment without having to redo the rest of the path. The variety of weapons also don't seem to matter so much -- for example, many of rifle choices for assaulter class don't seem to offer distinct advantage compared to e.g. P90 or SAR-18 option. Lastly, it's better if some action options are added, e.g. ability for a team member to look around and clear the room before moving. At the moment, there's only option to look at one direction, confirm that it's clear, move slightly, look at another direction, confirm that it's clear, and so on. Another ability that will come in handy is the ability to synchronize team member to only move after a flashbang (without using go codes), the ability to specify alternate action (e.g. when the door that is supposed to be breached is already opened by someone else), and ability to combine actions on one item during planning (e.g. unlock the door, then throw a flashbang through it).Having said that, those issues are minor, and I still highly recommend this game.

												Overall: DecentLikes:- A lot of content- Has procedurally-generated levels- Supports player-created contentDislikes:- Planning out your strategy takes quite a bit of time, even for relatively simple levels.  It's fun but it is also tiresome.- Controlling your characters in real time feels laggy because they move slower than your mouse, and inputs get queued.- I wish you could undo changes to your plan, and save your plans for later use.  I also wish you could edit a section of your route without erasing the subsequent path.- In campaign mode, once you leave a mission, your current state (health, deaths) is saved and you can't retry it from the original state you were in when you first played that mission.  Not a huge deal though.

Posted: September 8, 2016
												Show those doors who's the boss!Non maymay review: A perfect blend of real time and turn based strategy brought to you by the tactical pause button. It could be compared to Breach and Clear, although there are many differences. B&C is closer to turn based strategy, although the turns happen in real time, and has arguably better graphics. Doorkickers instead, has a an, also arguably, better general gameplay, despite lacking some of the RPG elements that help Breach & Clear add some depth. Like B&C, has tons of levels and lots of replayability if you like unlocking weapons and gear. Its already long shelf life is lengthened even more with the addition of mods (deploying snipers is nice!). My dream game undoubtedly has a combat system like Doorkickers. You can plan, hit play, pause, correct your plan on the go... I wish Jagged Alliance: Back In Action was this fluid. I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

And so is the soundtrack. Nothing spectacular.The controls are not the best, as drawing lines around and on top of existing ones can get quite glitchy.Everything said, this game is definitely different from anything I've played so far.I recommend this game for anyone looking for a new experience in the ‘tactical’ department.

Posted: January 17, 2016
												Ignore the time Steam says I have played. I have played about 14 hours of the game overall, most of it done offline while I was traveling.Similar to: Hotline Miami, Rainbow Six 3, SWAT 4Pros-Simple controls that anyone can pick up.-Can be played with one hand.-Game mechanics may be simple, but allow for extremely complex strategies to be played out.-Versetile level editor.-Lots of content in the game, hundreds of standalone missions ranging in difficulty, as well as a handful of campaigns lasting 1 to 2 hours each.-Randomized mission generator.-Scenario Variety-Perfect game to play on a laptop if you have a mouse.-Officer and Squad progression. (new skills, weapons, and classes to unlock)-Pause and play allows you to assess the situation on an action by action basis, giving the player time to think and plan.-Good soundtrack.-Playing with your own music/podcast in the background takes nothing away from the game. Cons-Enviroments can get repetitive. (The level design is varried, I'm talking about the way they look)-Controls don't work well when trying to play in real time.-Some of the bigger levels can get tedious, especially if you are stuck looking for the last enemy, hostage, bomb, etc.-How fast your guys react to getting shot at is random at times.-Steath is underdeveloped.ConclusionThis is the most fun I have had in an RTS ever. This is coming from someone who doesn't really like RTS games. I decided to give this game a shot, mainly because I am a fan of squad based Tactical FPS's (Swat 4 and Arma 3 being my favorites) and this game shared the same concepts. Overall, the game is accessible, but still has the complexity to please seasoned RTS verterans.Recommended to: Players who are looking for an accessible game that has a challenging tactical experience that does not rely on clunky UI or twitch shooting.9 out of 10

Posted: May 15, 2015
												A real-time with pause game that requires you to plan carefully before engaging the bad guys. The squad as a whole could level up, earning you 'doctrines' to spend on the provided tech tree. Each squad member could also level up to improve their stats. You gain 'stars' after each successful mission, which you can spend on unlocking new weapons/armors/items that you can assign to any squad member. You could play the built-in missions, generate random ones, or create your own with the editor.So, yes, the game is worth every penny.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												Door Kickers is a game about commanding 2 to 8 armed officers, and fighting randomly generated terrorists through premade maps.This game's controls are simple and easy to understand, but can also provide the ability to execute advanced commands and the ability to co-ordinate your team.There are 5 classes to choose from, I have unlocked only 4 at the time of writing this review, and I can say that the shield has served me practically no use, although the other 3 classes (Pointman, Assaulter, Breacher) have proved most useful and indespensible aspects of a successful team.The way of customizing loadouts is using a currency called stars. You unlock these stars by completing missions and completing certain criteria, the criteria to earn a full three stars are to not lose a single unit and to score a time below the limit given. This must not be confused with a speedrun, as the game can be paused and tactics and actions can be prepared in the paused state, ready to be performed when the game is running again. 15 seconds ingame can become a whole minute if you pause a lot.However, if you spend your stars on bad weapons, or on one class alone, you may find yourself in a whole that you dug yourself into, and I thoroughly dislike the randomly generated terrorists, and I found my troops sometimes turning their back to danger despite my orders.(Edit 1) In the campaigns, which are a series of missions in which soldiers are perminently KIA for the duration of it if lost, I have found that soldiers that are killed are lost, and their stat gains from promotions are also lost. This adds a benefit to not just going ham and sending all of your men in to be slaughtered, which is always a plus for an RTS.But overall, I would recommend this game, I felt like quite a badass.And if you need an arbitrary rating, it gets my 8/10.

Posted: December 26, 2015
												Whilst it's good fun to plan your attack the point of doing so is ruined somewhat by the randomness of the game.An entrance that can work twice in a row can fail on the third because the enemies suddenly kill you whereas previuosly they didn't. I'm assuming that this is because they have an element of randoness when they are generated or open fire.In other games this would be fair enough as it keeps the level from becoming too linear however in a game that tries to sell itself on the planning aspect it becomes pretty annoying quite quickly.You can edit the maps to remove the random enemy start points and play each one as a custom map but this means you don't get the progression of characters and equipment etc. that you would playing them normally.Maybe it's just me as I think the game would work much better if it were more like a puzzle game where your planning actually counted for more. I am still recommending it if picked up in a sale.

Posted: January 1, 2016
												A tactical game where you take control of a swat team that you can customize with dozens of guns and items. As far as guns go, there are pretty much 4 types, and there's no real incentive to use anything other than the best gun of each type: either the best SMG for close quarters, the best shotgun, the best rifle, or the best silenced weapon. Pistols behave similarly. However, the core strategy experience is deep and addicting. The tutorial is really insufficient to acquaint you with new features of the game, as I was still discovering "advanced" controls after 10+ hours.That said, holy fudge, this game is tons of fun. As you start to master the controls, the rush and satisfaction of breaching a door, placing a few well placed bullets into the generic "terrorists", and saving the hostages, you'll forget all about any problems. Plus, the game itself comes with a robust level editor, and custom content is worth the price of admission on its own. The game comes (right now) with 120+ individual missions and 6 campaigns. It's a lot of content, and with about 20 hours logged I'm done with the 4 shortest campaigns, and a mere <30 missions. I've unlocked everything except the clearly worse guns, but I'm still playing like there's more to unlock- the game is just that fun.If you like strategy games or are looking for a unique SWAT type sim, listen to the hype- this game is GREAT.

Posted: June 24, 2016
												I feel that this is a very good game. I like the game concept and pacing of the missions. The missions are interesting but short enough. The game mechanics are not difficult to learn, but level design and the equipment customization ability allows one to try multiple approaches to complete a mission. With good planning of equipment and paths, the team can complete the actual mission in very short time. There are some things that can be improved. For example, the UI makes it difficult to pick individual team members when they stand very closely together. Path creation UI can also be improved, e.g. to allow easy modification of an early segment without having to redo the rest of the path. The variety of weapons also don't seem to matter so much -- for example, many of rifle choices for assaulter class don't seem to offer distinct advantage compared to e.g. P90 or SAR-18 option. Lastly, it's better if some action options are added, e.g. ability for a team member to look around and clear the room before moving. At the moment, there's only option to look at one direction, confirm that it's clear, move slightly, look at another direction, confirm that it's clear, and so on. Another ability that will come in handy is the ability to synchronize team member to only move after a flashbang (without using go codes), the ability to specify alternate action (e.g. when the door that is supposed to be breached is already opened by someone else), and ability to combine actions on one item during planning (e.g. unlock the door, then throw a flashbang through it).Having said that, those issues are minor, and I still highly recommend this game.

Posted: September 1, 2015
 Door Kickers - Good, in a punch your screen kind of way. I quite like Door Kickers, it's a pretty fun tactical game with some basic in reality. I found using realistic tactics really does help complete the missions however that doesn't mean it'll work every time. The game isn't without it's downsides, I often found myself wondering why I was only allowed two SWAT officers to raid a massive building full of hostages but I guess it's supposed to add to the challenge? I first brought this game before the existance of doctrines and when all weapons where free, I found the update to be pleasant to begin with as it gave you something to work towards however again, I soon found myself questioning the logic to it all. Why aren't my officers allowed the tools they need for the job? Why am I taking a sqaud of undertrain and inexperienced officers in to this highly dangerous situation? So yes, the game is damn frustrating at times but that's all part of the experience I suppose. There is nothing quite like trying over and over again to get that perfect run, quick, clean and without injury's. I often found that even if the game made me rage quit I'd be back on it minutes after trying to best myself. If you like tactical games then this is definatly one for you - if you can look past all it's minor annoyances.

												Well, I took a chance on a cheap game that had some postitive reviews.  I am glad I did, this game is great, I cant stop playing.  Even when I die over and over, I dont get upset. Posted: June 24, 2016
												I feel that this is a very good game. I like the game concept and pacing of the missions. The missions are interesting but short enough. The game mechanics are not difficult to learn, but level design and the equipment customization ability allows one to try multiple approaches to complete a mission. With good planning of equipment and paths, the team can complete the actual mission in very short time. There are some things that can be improved. For example, the UI makes it difficult to pick individual team members when they stand very closely together. Path creation UI can also be improved, e.g. to allow easy modification of an early segment without having to redo the rest of the path. The variety of weapons also don't seem to matter so much -- for example, many of rifle choices for assaulter class don't seem to offer distinct advantage compared to e.g. P90 or SAR-18 option. Lastly, it's better if some action options are added, e.g. ability for a team member to look around and clear the room before moving. At the moment, there's only option to look at one direction, confirm that it's clear, move slightly, look at another direction, confirm that it's clear, and so on. Another ability that will come in handy is the ability to synchronize team member to only move after a flashbang (without using go codes), the ability to specify alternate action (e.g. when the door that is supposed to be breached is already opened by someone else), and ability to combine actions on one item during planning (e.g. unlock the door, then throw a flashbang through it).Having said that, those issues are minor, and I still highly recommend this game.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												This is the closest game I could find to be considered a hidden gem. And I think is deserves that title.Take control of a SWAT squad during many different terrorist encounters, thoroughly cleaning out the building by the time your done. Use the many squad members you make in your down time to change your strategy for each level.Most of the time you'll have to save hostages, but you will encounter the occasional bomb, arrest warrent, drug situation, or have to just clean house. As you complete missions, you level your used squad members, not only improving their combat skills, but also giving you doctorine points. Doctorine points being used to upgrade the different classes' effectiveness.You'll meet alot of doors blocking your way along you career. But kicking them down isn't the only option. You can silently open them, loudly flash them, or (still loudly) plant C4 to burst them open. And that's just normal doors. You'll also face locked doors that can't silently be opened, but have to be picked, which will alert enemies close enough to hear it. As you can see, this is were the strategy kicks in. To this day I can hear "loud?" ringing in my ears while playing PAYDAY 2. As much as it hurts me to say this so blandly, "you can go in loud, or sneak in silent." But I have to cut this guide short before it gets to long.IN SUMMARY: GOOD GAME, BAD PRICE: "CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN GEM"

Posted: December 24, 2016
												Very enjoyable, softcore-tactical, quick to play timesink. I got it on sale but it is easily worth 10 quid.I liked Frozen Synapse, making detailed plans for goons to follow and succeeding in beating enemies down via superior tactics. Unfortunately, Frozen Synapse is pretty hardcore and I enjoy being able to kick back and watch my men act. Feels like Door Kickers jumps right in, neither being too complicated, nor being too simplistic.There are issues with the game that feel a bit annoying, such as flashbangs not going where they're supposed to go (which I know very well from SWAT4), path editing not being meant for complex planning and some minor UI stuff. However, the game feels polished, solid and well-designed.Gameplay is generally bang boom bang, so don't expect too much in terms of policework. You're gunning down dozens of armed guys and usually within a narrow timeframe.If the trailer had you excited, buy this thing. It's well worth it.

Posted: February 18
												Door Kickers is a top down strategy game where you plan out routes for you swat units to take and clear out the baddies.  There's customization, classess, the every slight presence of RPG elements, and robust and rewarding gameplay.But this is a game I am torn on.  On one hand, it is very well made strategic and tactical experience with LOADS of content to keep you busy if you love it. However, even with its varying levels of difficulty and what should be endless costomization options to suit each level, the gameplay gets stale very fast.  Often times, I found myself asking why there were so many levels because they all blend together into this ubiqitous expereince so quickly.  To be clear, I absolutely love the gameplay and all of the ideas that are brought to the table, but it is needlessly big.  It's like going to see a movie that has a lot of good stuff but it goes on an hour too long.  Now in videogames, that shouldn't be a problem, you just don't play the extra stuff, but here's the rub:  you are paying for it.The $20 price tag is my only issue with the game.  Other than that, it's perfect for a quick play every now and then and delivers all that it should.  If you like strategy games and it's on sale for say, $10 I highly recommend it, but there isn't enough here to justify the 20 dollar tag.
