Posted: March 3
												This is an entertaining little casual strategy game. It's a bit like Frozen Synapse, but without turns. Instead, you have the ability to control one of your team at a time in real time (not generally recommended but sometimes it's just more convenient) or pausing and drawing up a detailed plan.For planning you drag a footpath, and set waypoints. Waypoints occur any time you want to do something other than keep walking. For example, you can change or lock facing, hold position and fire until your cone of sight is clear, toss a flashbang, perform some form of breaching maneuver, or collect evidence. You can also set up to four 'hold' points--very useful for keeping all your team working in unison.In the beginning, you'll probably use none of that and just drag your squad members around, but if you want the best results, you'll learn to use and execute plans. It's much easier to clear a house with a team working simultaneously like a tidal way flowing through it, each member clearing their sector and relying on their teammates to do the same, than it is to try and move them one at time, no matter how good your leapfrogging skills are.In a sense, the midgame moves from a strategy game to more of a puzzle feel. This is becuase once a map is generated, it remains the same, so you can grind on it until you get a plan that works as well as you want it to. It's a very satisfying feeling when you get a multistage plan to clear a building and can do it all in one go, triggering phases as you go. A skilled player will spend the bulk of their time in planning mode. A masterful player will not only spend most of their time in planning mode, they'll only use it once at the beggining of the mission.It feels like it was ported from a tablet game. The biggest reason it feels like that is that all levels are on a single screen--though some missions have multiple levels (floors). This means that no matter how big a level is, there's no scrolling around the map, and no need for a mini-map. It's all handled by scaling the sprites instead, so that on a simple small map, everthing is bigger, and on the largest maps, everything gets a bit small, and there is no option to zoom in. That can make certain forms of breaching a door more difficult to plot because sometimes waypoints will end up so close together it's hard to get the right one. This mainly happens to me when using a shieldbearer to kick down a door, take a step into a small room that's probably empty anyway, and back out. It can be done, but sometimes it's a bit fussy to get it done.The structure of the game is a bit odd. You are forced to grind a bit at the beginning on single missions before campaign mode unlocks. This works in your favour though, as the prescripted single missions gradually increase in difficulty, but don't penalize you if someone get injured or killed during the mission. In a campaign mission, the injured require time to heal, and dead remain dead--though it's completely up to you whether or not you want to accept those results or not. You can always choose to restart the level and try again.Your plan will remain intact by default, and you can tweak it so it works better.Tweaking a plan is where the game falls on it's face the most. Some adjustments can be made cleanly, but others will wipe out every step past the adjustment. Further, some waypoints are harder to revise than others for no discernable reason. Chiefly, if you have a waypoint to wait for a signal to continue, you can't delete that waypoint until you toggle the signal at that waypoint off.To clarify, lets say you have a plan laid out and at a certain point you want a member of your team to wait for an "alpha" command. This would mean that they would execute every command up until that waypoint, and then hold position until you hit the "A" or "1" key. This would be done by right-clicking the waypoint, and clicking the "A" button on the submenu. Every other command on the submenu can be wiped out by deleting a waypoint, but a waypoint to wait for a trigger like that cannot be deleted (in spite of being able to right click it and select "Delete Waypoint") unless you first right click it and click the "A" on the submenu again.It can be frustrating if you haven't figured that out--and it's something the game does not tell you.The upgrading system is a bit of a joke. As you do missions, your team will rank up, and once your team has ranked up enough, new jobs and campaigns become available. Further, as you complete missions you earn stars to use to unlock new guns and equipment. But XP and stars are easy to grind for thanks to a very simple random mission generator that gives out more or less the same rewards, regardless of the actual difficulty of the mission--at least as far as stars are concerned. No mission yields more than three stars, no matter how difficult or complex the map. This means you can grind through maps containing one or two small rooms, stuffed with easy targets and three star them every time with very little effort. In an hour or so, you should be able to unlock all the jobs, and all the equipment you find interesting.There is also a sort of "talent tree" called doctrines. As your team levels, you gain points to spend, but there really aren't that many things to spend them on, and they're all or nothing, so in the same time you unlock all the jobs and all the equipment you want, you can complete the entire doctrine tree. It's busywork more than an accomplishment.There are also some menu... quirks. If you watch a replay, the only way to get back to selecting missions is to back out to the main menu again. This isn't that big of a problem though, because after a couple replays, you won't use that function very often.The replay function has two significant flaws beyond the menu issue. The first is that to watch a replay is to save it--there is no choice in the matter. The second is that there is no apparent way to watch the replay without the plan marks. I don't want to see my waypoints in the replay, I just want to watch my team flow through an enemy stronghold like a force of nature. That isn't an option, which cuts into the uh... replay value of the replay feature.It's not a AAA game, and it isn't trying to be. But for what it is, it's satisfying (provided you aren't paying full price). I didn't (and wouldn't) pay $20 for it. I wouldn't be happy if I'd paid more than about $10.  It's not a bad game, just overpriced IMSO.
